story:
YEMADA Farm

  • YEMADA Farm it s a community for people to live together and grow in harmony with the Nature. We are a group of friends with a similar vision of being set sufficient, having natural houses made out of clay, Integral education for ourselves and the children. Once, we believe in human evolution we need spaces for exploring our passions, music, dance , circus, so we decide to build a Dome where we can explore what we Love and share with others.
  • This campaign is a way to open the door to people to come and be part of the realisation of this dream and at the same time help us to pay the Dome. We are people that live in a simple way and without fix jobs, investing our time in building a community that can be an example for people to get inspired. So, the Dome it s a great step forward, so we can start to open the doors and do more courses at our farm!
  • This Dome it s dream that we have since long time! Now it s true, it already exist. We just need to pay 5000 euros, and you are part of this reality, once you will come to enjoy this Dome and also the full Yemada Farm experience!!

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We already paid 5000 Euros and now we need to pay the other 5000 euros to Iris, a friend that sold us the Dome and gave us the chance to have enough time to raise funds for paying the rest.
  •  We offer you amazing perks that will give you the chance to come to our farm, to visit, to relax,to learn, to get inspired, to spend some time with us or even to participate in the diferent  Workshops that we propose for you: Music, Dance and Circus!!!!
  • All the funds will go to pay the Dome and for getting the infrastructures that we need to make it more comfortable(solar panels, eco-toilet).

The Impact

 This Dome is one Place dedicated to Human Evolution, for Integral Education, for adults and Kids explore their authenticity!

  Some of us had the chance to live in Auroville,India for several years and we had the experience of building amazing infrastructures where we could really enjoy all the activities that we Love to do! Now we want to create a place similar to Auroville where people from all over the world can come and change their lives!

The good news is that the Dome already exist!!So, we just need the support of each one of you! If everybody can give some money according to their possibilities and to which perk they want, we ll make it together!!!

 

Risks & Challenges

  • We took 2 months to build it up, specially because we had to open the place by hand , without using any machine and its a 10 square meter dome, what means was a lot of digging all by hand. Than it was a challenge to build the structure, because we are not dome experts, but we had enough power to do it and the support of Pedro Barros, the Dome creator, that answer all the phone calls with all the doubts that we had!Thank you all that already helped!
  • Now the great challenge is just to pay it, because we don't want to abandon the farm and go work faraway and leave the fruit trees, the garden, all the Social Projects that we part of. So, we prefer to trust that everything will flow and with all the support of family, friends and people that believe in this Project we ll make it!

Other Ways You Can Help

 Please spread the word, so more people can support this campaign and also be part of this Project of Yemada Dome!!!

story:
Short Summary

Over the past 6 years Black Cat Artspace has hosted over 180 exhibitions and events in a wide variety of mediums, by local emerging and established artists, collectives, and curators. Filling a much needed niche in Toronto of both a place to get started as an exhibiting artist, from students to established artists and the go to venue for featured exhibitions as part of Toronto's cultural festivals, our space has proven to be available to all, inclusive, and much needed!

But it’s more than just a venue. As an alternative space, Black Cat doesn’t have to follow any particular discourse, aesthetic, or rules. It’s fluid, and what you make of it. Spaces like Black Cat play an important role in the Toronto arts scene as a meeting place, a venue for free expression and a zone for experimentation.

Therefore, it is with great excitement that we are announcing the launch of a new Gallery and Studio space at 1785 St. Clair West that will be run with the same ethos. We’ll be opening this December with the 5th annual Salon of Inclusiveness group show. It’s going to take a bit of work to transform it from its current state into a gallery, but with the help of our community and long hours we are confident to complete it all. 

 

Updates: Mural on the Exterior, by Chris Perez

 

What We Need & What You Get

We've already got the keys and begun work on the new gallery space, by contributing to this campaign this space is your space! All money raised will goto the following needs:

  • Renovation materials, and select labour (for what we're not experts at ourselves)
    • Including, two new mini-split electric heaters to heat the space in the winter
    • 2x4's for framing walls / drywall and supplies
    • Track lighting and fixtures, electrical work.
    • Paint sprayer rental, and gallons upon gallons of white paint.
    • New toilet, updates to the washroom facilities.
    • + more
  • Funds to commission a large scale mural on the front and side of the building.
  • Initial production budget for our first shows, marketing, and PR. 

We are open to more ideas, and suggestions always.

The Impact

We want everyone who contributes to the success of this project to benefit and enjoy what we create, each reward will provide value beyond its dollar amount to the community we've built over the last 6 years and to which will continue to grow with a new audience!

  • If you're an artist / photographer / illustrator / musician / installation artist and more this space is available to you, and your contribution will unlock it. 
  • If you're a neighbour or patron, you are the catalyst to the creative change and energy this will bring to the area.
  • If you're a guest or visitor to any of our past exhibitions and events, this space is your new destination.

Any amount helps make this happen. 

The First Show at Black Cat - Showroom 

We will kick it all off with our largest and most inclusive group show of the year:

Our 5th annual Salon of Inclusiveness 2018, Holiday Show + Sale

 

Exhibition runs from December 6th 2018 –Jan 17th 2019

SUBMISSION DEADLINE: November 25th, 2018

The CALL FOR SUBMISSIONS is open to EVERYONE:

http://submit.theblackcat.to

https://www.facebook.com/events/253151055377614/

Before:

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by sharing this campaign within your own community and network! 

https://igg.me/at/blackcatshowroom/

Submit your work to our Call for Submissions - Salon of Inclusiveness 2018, Holiday Show

https://submit.theblackcat.to

More info:

https://www.facebook.com/TheBlackCatTO/

https://www.facebook.com/Black-Cat-Showroom-1808262815966675/

https://www.instagram.com/theblackcat_to/

https://twitter.com/TheBlackCat_TO

story:
Short Summary

We are Apapachoa. The "Eco-Cultural center Apapachoa”, just opened its doors in the middle of the natural reserve “El Bajo”, below the dramatic hills of El Crucero a unique landscape in Nicaragua. It is located just about 30 minutes from busy Managua in the rural community of Santa Julia. Apapachoa in Nahuatl, one of the original indigenous language of Nicaragua means “to hug with your soul”.

We promote arts, music, sports as well as organic, bio-intensive agriculture and permaculture. In brief we are cultural center in the middle of a 2300 acres jungle trying to reach sustainability based around 3 axes: the agriculture, the cultural center and the eco-tourism. 

We believe that through ART, music and culture we can create social impact. 

That is why we decided to bring the Fabulous Artist Jelili Atiku to come and work with us. Jelili is a renown Nigerian artist that has been working all around the globe for the rights of the people. He has a deep human knowledge and that is why we need him to be our first resident Artist! 

You can learn more about him here: http://www.jeliliatiku.webs.com

What We Need & What You Get

In brief we need $4000 to get him here from Lagos. We divide it that way: $2200 for his flight, $100 for his Visa, $1700 for his stay here and materials to work with.If you help us you can get a range of things from Apapachoa.

The Impact

We believe that Art can heal many wounds and help create new realities.

Jelili defines his work this way: "I have put my art at service of the prevailing concerns of our times; especially those issues that threatening our collective existence and the sustenance of our universe. Therefore, the contents of these concerns ranging from psychosocial and emotional effects of the traumatic events: violence, war, poverty, corruption, climate change, etc.,that associated with our warring world dominate my artistic forms. Doing drawing, installation sculpture, video and performance art; I strive to help viewers understand the world and expand their understanding and experiences, so that they can activate and renew their lives and environments.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, please help us share the campaign as much as you can on all your social networks and platforms. We are also very open to future artists collaborations, so don't hesitate in sending ideas and proposals to apapachoanicaragua@gmail.com

We will be forever grateful!

Love,

the Apapachoa Family :)

 

Thank you to Eduardo Spiegler for the beautifully made video

story:
Short Summary

I am John Kennedy – real name. I’m producing a documentary about people leaving prison for PBS Frontline and the New York Times, I play in a punk band, and I also do some street art. I'm working with Manoj Kesavan of the Boom Festival in Charlotte, the painter Nick Napoletano, and Buff Faye, the current reigning Miss Charlotte Pride. Nick is an incredible painter – his paintings look like the Sistine Chapel. We are creating a large wall mural during the Boom Festival - starting in April 7-10 at the Plaza Midwood Neighborhood. The image will be based on a play-on-words, that Charlotte is called the Queen City – “The Drag Queens of Queen City.”  This mural will hopefully be the first of a series. It will be playful, cool, visually fantastic and a celebration of underground culture, local drag history/legends and Charlotte being an inclusive and progressive city. The Drag Queens we will showcase are: Boom Boom LaTour, Toni Lenoir, Kasey King, and Brandy Alexander, who recently passed away.  

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are raising $7500 to pay for the artist, paint, equipment, and to create 5000 postcards.
  • At the $500 level of support you will get your name or the name of your company on the back of the postcard. The postcard will be made of the mural and distributed to stores, restaurants, and music venues in Charlotte. 
  • For donation less than $500 - please come down to the Boom Festival and meet John, Nick, and Buff Faye.
  • We will continue to fundraise until we cover these costs.

The Impact

    • We support LGBT rights and alternative communities, like the drag queen community in Charlotte. We are hoping that this mural honors our local drag history and helps Charlotte to define itself an an inclusive city. 
    • Buff Faye is the reigning Miss Charlotte Pride, and she works toward creating an open, accepting, and fun community. Nick Napoletano's painting can be seen on billboards in Charlotte, supported by the Arts and Science Council. John Kennedy is an art activist and project manager who had managed productions and campaigns for the Gates Foundation, UN Millennium Campaign, Open Society Foundations, New York Times, as well as others. 
    • Murals are unique in art, that as public works depicting individuals from a community they help a neighborhood define itself. 

Risks & Challenges

We have three weeks to raise $7500. The Boom Festival is committed to finding us a wall in the Plaza Midwood Neighborhood in Charlotte, NC. We are committed to using our personal networks or friends and activists to fund this mural. We feel it is an important and timely statement for Charlotte to make, to show support of its alternative communities. John Kennedy will sit down with anyone who is interested in this project. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ok - I need your help. Basically we are making a large public mural in Charlotte that will coincide with their BOOM Festival on April 7-10. Charlotte is the "Queen City" and the mural will be "The Drag Queens of Queen City." We need this to be real for this community. We need people to not only share, but to back this and ask their friends to share. If you know people who are very passionate about the drag community, about gay/lesbian/bi/transgender rights please talk with them. We need to build up a huge network within three weeks and talk to as many people who could be significant funders as soon as possible. So - please don't just nod your head - get behind this as a group of friends. We want Charlotte to really own this mural.
  • You can always use Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Bendrigg Trust

We are a registered charity and outdoor centre specialising in activities for disabled and disadvantaged people from across the country. Each year we support around 3,000 people access activities they never dreamt possible due to their disability or disadvantage. 

Our Art for All programme is unique and combines our work with outdoor adventure and education with the creative arts. Working with a local artist, Emily, we ensure that our users have the chance to express themselves, find hidden talents and develop their creative skills in an inclusive and supportive environment.  
By supporting our project you will not only be helping individuals but also families and whole communities. Often a person with a disability cannot access a local art club simply because they don't have accessible facilities, or the staff with experience to support them. Our project believes that art is for everyone and with your help we can achieve that aim. 

What We Need

To continue offering Art for All for the rest of the year we need £6,000. These funds will go towards art materials such as clay, paint and felt as well as employing our Artist on a freelance basis - approximately 2 days per week. Having the flexibility of working freelance allows Emily to run weekend clubs for families, weekday sessions for schools and evening sessions for our residential users. 
It costs around £1,000 per month to run Art for All and support around 50 disabled and disadvantaged people - that's just £25 per person for a new and memorable experience they will cherish for years to come. 
If we don't reach our target, the funds raised will still be able to support this project but for a shorter timescale and if we raise more we will be able to continue the project for longer, helping more people in the process! 
We have some fantastic rewards for you if you do decide to support us with a donation. From free Arty Pants sessions, tickets to our annual Ceilidh event, a personal thank you from our Artist and much more - grab yourself a perk before they disappear! 

The Impact

Many people take day to day activities for granted. People with a disability or families with a disabled member know that suddenly the world becomes a more challenging place. Perceptions of ability change and these can often be more debilitating than any condition. 
Art for All allows people to express themselves, which is especially important for those with non-verbal ability or communication difficulties. They can create a piece or work and take something home they can feel proud of. Simply having access to a fully inclusive studio and learning new skills with new materials can be very empowering. Art for All brings people together from all walks of life, fostering a sense of understanding and being a driving force for social change in the wider community. 
Without your support we cannot provide these experiences, effect these changes and bring simple joy to so many. Without your support many people with disabilities, both in the local area and further afield, would be unable to access such a unique, beneficial and positive experience. But don't just take our word for it....
"It's set up so your child can really achieve something satisfying, There's no way we would manage to create all these creative and sensory experiences at home. It's brilliant."
"...a rare thing indeed, and much valued for the well-being of our whole family." 
"Every single member of staff goes that extra mile to ensure that my role as Project Leader is made as easy as possible and that the children and young people achieve a huge amount whilst having the time of their lives."
"What a wonderful place for anyone to visit. It was a great reminder to all grown ups on how anything can be achieved with the right attitude and motivation."
"My kids’ achievements at Bendrigg have outstripped anything I ever thought possible. The feel-good factor here is brilliant...they come away feeling on top of the world." 

Other Ways You Can Help

Support can come in many forms and we value them all! We'd love you to make a donation but if you can't then maybe you can help in other ways - share our page, tell your friends about our project, host a bake sale, offer a perk for others who donate - the list is huge! 


Thank you for your support and we look forward to keeping you up to date with the progress of our project: Art for All!

"...a rare thing indeed, and much valued for the well-being of our whole family." 
"Every single member of staff goes that extra mile to ensure that my role as Project Leader is made as easy as possible and that the children and young people achieve a huge amount whilst having the time of their lives."

"What a wonderful place for anyone to visit. It was a great reminder to all grown ups on how anything can be achieved with the right attitude and motivation."
"My kids’ achievements at Bendrigg have outstripped anything I ever thought possible. The feel-good factor here is brilliant...they come away feeling on top of the world." 
    
Other Ways You Can Help

 Support can come in many forms and we value them all! We'd love you to make a donation but if you can't then maybe you can help in other ways - share our page, tell your friends about our project, host a bake sale, offer a perk for others who donate - the list is huge! 

Thank you for your support and we look forward to keeping you up to date with the progress of our project: Art for All!

story:
What's is Savannah?

Savannah is a space in which we both play. Savannah is an exotic landscape that is seemingly monotonous, while it actually holds the potential for sudden abrupt change. We generate the exotic based on our own personal histories and we let this clash on stage. By doing so, we construct a new idea of exoticism.


Our process has had two phases so far. The first took place in Zurich, in September 2015, where we had our first residency in Tanzhaus Zurich. Marc Walter Streit and Catja Loepfe, artistic directors of Tanzhaus Zurich, believed in us enough to give us a space to test out our ideas. As we planted the first layers of Savannah, the result started looking promising, and we got invited to show the work in Tanztage in Berlin, a festival curated by Anna Muelter.

As we continued to work on Savannah, the need emerged for having a third person that could manipulate the space while we played and that could observe us. A person who could establish a bridge between us and the fantasy world. That was when we invited Yorgos Sapountzis to join us, and the piece became a trio.

We asked Marcelo Alcaide to style our costumes, and we added a layer of branding by wearing only adidas sportswear. Like this we shamelessly refer to the fetishization of brands in this world.


Savannah was very well received by the audience. We managed to bring together audience from the dance scene with people form other sectors that normally don’t go to the theater so much, like people in fashion, branding.... It is our belief that performance art nowadays can establish bridges between different areas of life and we feel that we Savannah we achieved this goal.

So now what?

 

Because of this inittial succes of Savannah, Tanzhaus Zurich, in collaboration with SudPol Lucerne, decided to offer us two more weeks of residency, during which we will work in a dance studio, have a place to live in Luzerne, and a presentation of the work, on the 15th of October. 

 

What do we want to do?

 

During these two weeks we want to shorten the piece, complexify the choreographic language that we started, and reflect on the specific direction this journey is taking. 


And that's why we're here.

 

We want to gather 2500 euros and this money would go to traveling costs from Berlin to Switzerland, production money for the piece, living expenses in Switzerland, and a chance to be able to give a fair remuneration to everyone involved.

 

We will have the campaign running while the residency is happening so make sure to stay updated about the progress of Savannah! If you have any questions during this time and want to know more about the work, we will be more than happy to get back to you and we are happy to share the process with anyone who wants to know more about it.

Any little donation counts for us and we hope we can count on you. We want to bring everyone closer to our project and build bridges once again. If you want to be a part of the Savannah landscape, feel free to give what you can.

 

See you in Savannah!

story:
Tell me about yourself!

I am an artist living in Shizuoka, Japan. I started drawing from a young age. I remember my aunt gave me a set of crayons for my sixth birthday. Since then I've never stopped drawing. I work mainly in watercolour and sumi (a type of japanese black ink) and had my first solo exhibition in the summer of 2014.

How did you come up with Les Garcon Des Fleurs?

Recent advents in social networking platforms and technologies have given rise to entirely new kinds of relationships that can transcend the traditional concepts of honesty, transparency and intimacy.

I often post my art on instagram. A year ago I posted a nude portrait of a man which I did in sumi ink and ball point pen. I was surprised at the positive response I got and decided to ask one of my instagram followers to pose for me. This grew and grew and I've now done hundreds of portraits. Although I've never met any of the actual subjects of  my work I feel I share a connection with each of them that is very intimate, special and undeniable as a result of the process of creating this work.

What are the specs of this coloring book?

It will be a glossy hardcover A4 (21 x 29.7cm) 50+ pages of illustrations. 

What do you need from the crowd?

I basically need the budget for printing and shipping. 

What we can earn from this?

You will have an unique addition to your bookshelves, and when bored you can color it, brag it to your friends, and a good coffee table coaster too. 

Where we can see your other work?

You guys can check my instagram account @hajime_art and please feel free to follow my journey to turn this coloring book into a success.

www.instagram.com/hajime_art

If ever somebody can't donate how can they help?

Its easy, just talk about it to your friends, share this indiegogo campaign in your social media account! :)

story:
It's hard to believe that this will be XUZA's 4th year on the Playa, what was once just a Playa Dream has manifested into something truly amazing. 

Building an Art Car of this size is A LOT of work, more then I have ever anticipated, So many talented hands contributed to the project over the years and I can finally say, we are 90% complete.

We are looking to raise funds to help with routine maintenance, finish the new upgrades and transportation costs so we can once again WOW the residents of Black Rock City !  

Every year XUZA needs a new coat of UV Reactive White Paint, this is what makes XUZA Come Alive at night. Sadly the UV properties only last a few months at best.  This year she will need 5-6 gallons of paint @ $195.00 per gallon, and worth every drop!

We are adding new generators that are more efficient and a whole lot quieter and will be finishing up the entire façade plus you can never have too much lighting so we'll be adding more impressive LED features!

We couldn't be more ready to BURN!!!

Thank you for the support and we'll see ya on the PLAYA!!!!

Thanks again!

We Love You!

Mike C.
Justin - Case

 

Amazing Perks

 

Would you like to receive your Perk @ Burning Man 2017?

If you chose the Sticker, Dog Tags, Patch or LED Wristband you can choose to have it delivered to you at your Camp!  BRC has it's own Post Office and we can have your items shipped to your Camp Address!

Use the following format for your Playa Shipment:
Person/Camp Name, street Intersection
PO Box 149
Burning Man
Gerlach NV 89412

We're offering Beach Cruiser Playa Bikes again for 2017!
Don't go through the hassle of transporting and assembling a Bike when you can support an Art Project and have your Bike delivered to the Playa!

  • We maintain and service each Bike so you'll have reliable Playa transportation
  • Equipped with headlights and Lock
  • We deliver the bikes to the Playa where they will be  locked to the XUZA Transport Trailer. You will be the only person with the combo for your bike!
  • We will email you your bike combo and our camp address shortly before we embark on our journey to BRC. Come to our camp, unlock your bike and enjoy!


LED Slap Wristbands

The past two years our Green (2015) and Pink (2016) LED Slap Bands were a hit.. everyone wanted one. Make sure you guarantee yours today!


CUSTOM BURN BARRELS!

We are only offering three custom Burn Barrels this year!

Make sure you select the perk so we can have yours created and brought to you at Black Rock City!

story:
Introduction

"... the small but mighty Mother Tongue Publishing"- Kerry Clare, Pickle Me This

 

Canadian poet Mona Fertig has played a prominent role in the West Coast literary community for over forty years. In 1990 Mona and her husband, Renaissance man Peter Haase, moved from Vancouver to Salt Spring Island with their children and established (m)Other Tongue Press in their basement studio–first as a vibrant private press publishing gorgeous limited editions of Canadian poetry and book art, with letterpress and artwork by Peter–then evolving into a literary & art trade publisher when Mona decided it was time to bring her history and literary skills to the fore (her father was a brilliant but forgotten Vancouver artist) and shine a spotlight on the Unheralded Artists of British Columbia.

The Unheralded Artists of B.C. (UABC) is an unprecedented series of beautifully designed and well-researched books, illustrating and illuminating the lives and art of previously undocumented important artists of the 1900s-1960s, (there were over 17,000 artists working in B.C. during that time). Each book is printed in full colour and contains– months of research, over 100 images, an introduction, exhibition list, endnotes and index. The books are well-written by deeply committed B.C. writers and the stories are engaging and important.

Now, after nine years of hard work, amazing art sleuthing adventures; working with wonderful writers and artist’s families, great book celebrations and exhibitions, all while walking a financial tightrope, we are now reaching out for support for the publication of the next two titles, #9 and #10, in this unprecedented series

It is a big undertaking for a small publisher (one-woman office) to continue with such a visionary and labour intensive project without greater support. The artists featured are not famous or well-known, so it has been hard to match expenses with book sales, but that is exactly why these books are important; these artists inform the deeper narrative of our cultural history. This series is presently sustained by the passionate dedication of writers and freelance workers and self-sacrifice (Mona is the unpaid publisher) plus small grants and book sales. At Mother Tongue, quality is key, good writing and research is important and the books must be beautiful. Two titles have been finalists for the Roderick Haig-Brown Regional Prize and the Victoria Butler Book Prize, and the series can be found in better bookstores, libraries or ordered on-line from our website. Our sales are represented in North America by Heritage Group Distribution.

The donations received for this campaign will give us the funds to complete production and publication of the extraordinary Life and Art of Mary Filer-UABC #9 by Christina Johnson-Dean, due out in October 2016, and help us move forward on the remarkable Life and Art of Arthur Pitts-UABC #10 by Kerry Mason, due out in October 2017.

We hope you value the series and will support it and spread the word. Here are the titles we have published to date.

 

Mona Fertig and Peter Haase at the Burnaby Art Gallery exhibition opening and book launch for The Life and Art of George Fertig : Photo Ryan Mah

 

The Unheralded Artists of BC books:

#1  The Life and Art of David Marshall by Monika Ullmann, Introduction by Brooks Joyner, 2008.

#2  The Life and Art of Frank Molnar, Jack Hardman, LeRoy Jensen by Eve Lazarus, Claudia Cornwall, Wendy Newbold Patterson, Introduction by Max Wyman, Prefaces by Charles van Sandwyk, Jean Francois Guimond and Roy Patterson, 2009.

 #3 The Life and Art of George Fertig by Mona Fertig, Introduction by Peter Such, 2010.

#4 The Life and Art of Mildred Valley Thornton by Sheryl Salloum, Foreword by Sherrill Grace. Finalist for the Roderick Haig-Brown Regional Prize, 2011.

#5 The Life and Art of Ina D.D. Uhthoﬀ by Christina Johnson-Dean, Introduction by Pat Martin Bates. Victoria Butler Book Prize Finalist, 2012.

#6 The Life and Art of Edythe Hembroﬀ-Schleicher by Christina Johnson-Dean, Introduction by Kerry Mason, 2013.

#7 The Life and Art of Harry and Jesse Webb by Adrienne Brown, Introduction by Robert R. Reid, 2014.

#8 The Life and Art of Jack Akroyd by Peter Busby, Introduction by Paul Wolf, 2015.

 

And coming soon, with your help–

 

OCTOBER 2016–The Life and Art of Mary Filer by Christina Johnson-Dean: Mary Filer (1920-2016), born in Edmonton, was trained as a nurse, artist and art educator lived a vibrant life in Canada, the UK and the USA, as a muralist, a painter and glass sculptor, creating dazzling work in “cold” glass art in Victoria and Vancouver. During the 1950s, Filer studied under Group of Seven artist Arthur Lismer and painter John Lyman and taught university art. Filer moved to Victoria and Vancouver in the 60s where she was on the forefront of the glass art movement. Her involvement with architects and her partnership with Harold Spence-Sales, who started the first School of Urban Planning in Canada at McGill University, led to an honourary doctorate from Simon Fraser University in 1991 and an Allied Arts Silver Medal from the Royal Architectural Institute of Canada in 1992. Major examples of her cold glass sculpture are at SFU Harbour Centre and the Vancouver General Hospital. Her work is in numerous collections, including the National Gallery of Canada, the Toronto Art Gallery, the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts and the Art Gallery of Greater Victoria. This is an important story about an often neglected genre of Canadian art history.

Christina Johnson-Dean graduated from the University of California (B.A. in History, Art) and trained as a teacher. After teaching and travelling around the world, she settled in Victoria, B.C. to be near family. At the University of Victoria, she completed an MA (History in Art), serving as a teaching assistant and creating courses in local art history for Continuing Studies. Her publications include The Crease Family: A Record of Settlement and Service in British Columbia (B.C. Archives, 1981), “B.C. Women Artists 1885-1920” in British Columbia Women Artists (Art Gallery of Greater Victoria, 1985), and The Life and Art of Ina D.D. Uhthoﬀ and The Life and Art of Edythe Hembroﬀ-Schleicher (Mother Tongue Publishing, 2012, 2013).

 

 

Partial Adventures in Space 1 by Mary Filer, n.d., laminated clear, antique and shelled float glass, 14 1/2" x 22" x 13  1/2", Private Collection.

Mary Filer at Dawson College, St. John, Quebec, 1946

 

OCTOBER 2017–The Life and Art of Arthur Pitts by Kerry Mason: Arthur Pitts (1889-1972) was born in London, UK, at the end of the Victorian age and pursued a career of art and adventure, first in South Africa, then Canada. His early fascination with indigenous cultures led him on a lifelong quest to document in vibrant watercolours, sketches and photographs what Western society perceived to be “vanishing peoples,” just as George Catlin, Paul Kane, Edward Curtis and Emily Carr had also done. Pitts also created an entire series of landscapes, portraits and architectural subjects, commercial work and hundreds of cartoons for Punch magazine. Travelling more than 4,000 miles in British Columbia and Alaska, he produced a large body of work focusing on Coast Salish, Tlingit and Ktunaxa First Nations. Pitts’ fascinating story includes life as an artist in Vancouver in the 1920s and 1930s, where he attended the Vancouver School of Decorative and Applied Arts, studying under Fred Varley, Charles Scott and J.W.G. Macdonald; WWI trench warfare and a host of “struggle and prevail” adventures. His work is in the collections of the Royal BC Museum, the Glenbow Museum and several important private collections abroad. His story and art will be revealed for the first time.

Kerry Mason, B.A. M.A. is an art historian, author, curator and art consultant who lectures at the University of Victoria, University of Colorado, the Victoria College of Art and Vancouver Island School of Art, offering courses on Canada and British Columbia with a particular emphasis on Emily Carr and Indigenous Arts of the Northwest Coast. Kerry has  written many related articles, exhibit catalogues and a book, Sunlight in the Shadows: the landscape of Emily Carr, for Oxford University Press.  She has curated more than fifty exhibitions for the University of Victoria and other institutions throughout North America.

Blanket of Haida Princess, circa 1930, watercolour by Arthur Pitts

 

What We Need and Where It’s Going

 

Expenses are high for each Unheralded Artists of BC title. We publish one title a year. The grants we receive cover some editing and design costs, but not the writer’s research; nor all the editing, which includes indexing, endnotes and multiple copyedits and proofing; and permission charges for images as well as photography. They also do not cover the publisher’s honorarium, or all printing costs ( full colour, we keep our printing in Canada) and promotion for the series, which is key for its sustainability. The writer receives a small advance, 10% of royalties on sales and a standard contract. 

 

Here is a breakdown of expenses for UABC titles #9 and #10:

Editorial/Permissions/Photography: $5,000

Production and Design: $4,000

Printing and Binding: $13,000

Marketing: $6,000

Research and Travel: $2,000

Total budget for 2 UABC books: $30,000

We need to raise $20,000 for our campaign, and will apply for funding for $10,000 from arts councils. If we go beyond our goal, funds will go towards further promotion of the series and to paying the publisher, Mona Fertig, an honorarium towards her living expenses, as publishing is her full time job.

 

What You Will Receive in Return

 

During the campaign, we will be offering 35 amazing perks! Perks are gifts and incentives you receive when you make a donation. These perks will include our beautiful published books ( fiction, poetry, art), historical art by a variety of BC artists–Jack Akroyd, Takao Tanabe, George Fertig, Jack Hardman, Irene Hoffar Reid, Marguerite Pinney, Harry & Jessie Webb, Peter Paul Ochs, Rob Steeves, Mary Filer; our signed and numbered limited editions (letterpress and bookart); time to write or just get away in our lovely cosy Seaview Retreat on Salt Spring Island; Happy Hour with us in our sun porch on Salt Spring; a selection of UABC cards or custom printed letterpressed "Thank-you' cards; and an introduction to letterpress printing workshop for two, by Peter in our letterpress printing studio.

 

We will run our campaign for 33 days. If we reach out goal of $20,000 it will become an InDemand Campaign and people can still continue to donate and receive Perks after that date. If we do not reach our goal, we will still receive the amount raised, but the campaign will not become an InDemand Campaign.

 

Here are our Perks. There is something for everyone!

35 Gifts, one for every donation, ranging from $20 and up.

"Books & Cards," "Art" and "Experiences". Have a look.

Also scroll down and read Praise for the UABC series

 

F A B U L O U S    P E R K S!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you can’t donate to our campaign, there are other ways you can help. Share our campaign and tell others about it. Send it to friends, booklovers, artists, collectors, galleries, art lovers, historians and anyone else you know who you think might be interested. And go to our website if you want to see what other books we publish (fiction, poetry and non-fiction) http://www.mothertonguepublishing.com/

Thank-you to all who donated art for the cause and thanks to Mahyar Saeedi for video production.

Backers will receive regular updates on the progress of the campaign.

Thanks for your support!

best,

Mona Fertig and Peter Haase

 

Praise for The Unheralded Artists of BC Series:

 

“This important book reveals David Marshall as a sculptor of certain strength whose art grew throughout his lifetime to achieve a level of simplicity and power that arise from a clear statement of form and mass with absolute fidelity to each media–wood, stone and bronze–in which he worked. He is one of a generation of late modernists who have just left us–one thinks of Chillida or Oteiza in Spain, for example–whose work will endure. His accomplishment deserves to be better known in Canada, and at its best merits recognition worldwide.”–Barry Lord, President of Lord Cultural Resources

 

“Mother Tongue is to be congratulated for launching its timely Unheralded Artists of BC series.”-Maria Tippett, author

 

“Mona Fertig and her series Unheralded Artists of British Columbia has made a wonderful start on filling the gaps in our art history. There are lots of the unheralded in B.C. art, and I’m hoping that this series will go on and on.” –Cheryl Siegel, former Librarian/Archivist, Vancouver Art Gallery

 

“You are doing a great service for the cultural history of British Columbia by publishing these books, and I marvel that you can do it on such a modest budget.”–Michael J. Audain, The Audain Foundation 

 

“Mildred Valley Thonrton’s work is a documentation of an era…. I think she should have received the Order of Canada, but she didn’t live long enough.”—Christian Corbet, artist, historian and founder of the Canadian Portrait Academy

 

 “She (Mildred Valley Thornton) was gutsy. Her work reminds me a little of the freshness of Tom Thomson’s. She was really, really good. I hope she gets some recognition now.”—Gordon Smith, Canadian artist

 

“In a province with thousands of wonderful unheralded artists, Mother Tongue Publishing’s project is an important beginning to what will no doubt become a really significant series of books.” –Bill Jeffries, former Director, SFU Gallery

 

“Your father (George Fertig) was a mystic really. He had a clairvoyance of a very unusual and remarkable kind. He didn’t sell it. He didn’t advertise it. But he painted it.”—Leonard Woods, artist, teacher, writer

 

“The Burnaby Art Gallery is delighted to be a contributing partner in the George Fertig project. As an art gallery dedicated to British Columbia’s emerging and established artists, it is with great pleasure that we are able to include one of Mother Tongue Publishing’s unheralded artists within our exhibition program. Spiritually inspired and meticulously crafted, Fertig’s paintings seek to challenge each viewer to contemplate the relationships that exist between time and space and the subjects he has chosen to represent.” —Darrin Martens; former Director/Curator Burnaby Art Gallery

 

“Unfortunately, not all artists get recognition during their lifetime. George Fertig is a good example of a ﬁne painter whose sensible handling of both palette and perspective captured the BC landscape and who is only now being discovered. My painting of English Bay is a joy to live with and I observe the artist’s love of the subject every time I look at it.”—Uno Langmann; collector, art dealer

 

“Artist Ina Uhthoff, like her friend Emily Carr, held a passionate desire to see a permanent gallery in Victoria where people could experience art that reflected the modern era. At mid-century when the capital city had very little art presence, she was a driving force in support of founding what would become the Art Gallery of Greater Victoria. Her role in establishing the Gallery’s permanent home and hiring its first curator/director, Colin Graham, cannot be underestimated.”—Mary Jo Hughes, former chief curator, Art Gallery of Greater Victoria

 

“I was captured by the opening line and held fast til the last word. Christina Johnson-Dean has created a wonderfully lively, fast-moving, detailed life story of the remarkable artist Ina D.D. Uhthoff, linking her to the social and cultural worlds spanning Victoria, the Kootenays and Scotland. Johnson-Dean layers the fledgling art scene in British Columbia alongside personalities both well-known and newly rediscovered, teaching us about the times through rich and individualized voices. This beautifully illustrated, foundational study gives life to the early to mid-twentieth-century artistic scene, a period often omitted in scholarship.”—Kathryn Bridge, author, archivist and manager at the British Columbia Archives, Royal BC Museum

 

“For a variety of reasons, the work of many competent artists has never been shown in public exhibitions or been the subject of professional critiques during their lifetimes. Fertig is redressing this lack in the beautifully designed, articulate monographs in her new series, ensuring each subject a well-deserved permanent place in the public realm.”–Ann Rosenberg, Vancouver freelance critic and curator

 

 “Until now, Edythe Hembroff-Schleicher has been known in the broader Canadian art world only as the author of two wonderful books on Emily Carr, essential volumes in their field. With this book, we discover a Hembroff who was deeply involved in the art scene in British Columbia over a long period of time. During this involvement, she struggled through chronic illness, the Depression, World War II, earning a living, a number of relocations, several marriages and changing attitudes to women and the arts. Her work merits the study this book brings. Another significant aspect of Canadian art history revealed once again by Mother Tongue’s Unheralded Artists of BC series.”—Dennis Reid, professor, History of Art, University of Toronto, and author of A Concise History of Canadian Painting

 

“This (David Marshall) is a significant work in the sociology of art in Canada.”–George F. Drake, retired professor of Sociology, founder of Big Rock Garden Sculpture Committee, Bellingham, USA

 

“Thornton’s portrait collection is one of the most important historical documents of the twentieth century in Canada, particularly as it relates to the First Nations.”– Anthony Westbridge, Westbridge Fine Art Ltd.

 

"Fertig deserves far more support than she has so far for this fascinating & noble project"-Robert Amos, artist and writer

 

“Regional art histories are the foundational building blocks of the ever-evolving national narrative. Without a confident understanding of these local scenes, we can never speak authoritatively of the nature of our national accomplishment. In this regard, Mother Tongue’s new series must be enthusiastically applauded.”–Dennis Reid, professor, History of Art, University of Toronto, and author of A Concise History of Canadian Painting

 

“Contemporary and friend of Emily Carr, pioneering BC artist, art educator, critic and journalist, Ina Uhthoff is central to the history of twentieth century art in British Columbia. Her work features in private collections and public galleries, but in this book, Christina Johnson-Dean brings Uhthoff’s art and life into public focus today. A rich and rewarding read for both the specialist and layperson interested in this foundational era of Western Canadian art.”—Martin Segger, former director of the Maltwood Art Museum and Gallery at the University of Victoria

 

"The Unheralded Artists of BC series is a treasure. These books bring to light artists unfairly forgotten whose works amply reward our attention. Exquisitely produced, the series is an illuminating and inspiring resource for scholars, curators, artists and any reader with an interest in the diverse history of the visual arts in Canada."–Bob MacIntyre, preparator/exhibition coordinator, Burnaby Art Gallery

 

“Having performed as an art museum director and curator as well as a visual arts journalist and art historian on both sides of the 49th parallel for over forty years, I must admit that I have not, during that reflective period of time, ever experienced a more compelling, fascinating and original series of visual art publications than The Unheralded Artists of BC, a thoughtful and much-welcomed initiative.”–Brooks Joyner, director, Allentown Art Museum, USA

 

“Every gallery owner or curator interested in Canadian art history should welcome this significant series, which opens, for the first time, the door on unacknowledged artists and their forgotten legacies.”–Barrie Mowatt, President, Vancouver Biennale

 

“Edythe Hembroff-Schleicher will forever be known for her connection to Emily Carr, and this wonderful study illuminates much about that relationship. Hembroff-Schleicher was part of Carr’s life but also part of Carr’s legacy—the first to write a book-length appreciation of her work. Yet, as Christina Johnson-Dean reveals, Hembroff-Schleicher was a remarkable talent in her own right. With great ingenuity, she found a way to forge a career for herself as an artist, translator and writer. Much more than a footnote in Canadian Art history.”—Susan Crean, author of The Laughing One: A Journey to Emily Carr, nominated for a Governor General’s Award in Literature.

 

“The Webbs were among an important group of artists, poets and musicians to emerge in post-war Vancouver. Their abstraction was informed by prevailing trends in America and Europe but looked toward urban themes and nature with titles like Low Rent District and The Purchase of a Potted Pine by a Rare Bird. This book brings to light the valuable contributions they made to the emergence of contemporary art in Vancouver.”—Darrin Morrison, director/curator, West Vancouver Museum

 

“By publishing the Unheralded Artists of British Columbia series, Mother Tongue is making an impressive contribution to our visual art history.”—Gary Sim, editor/researcher for B.C. Artists

 

“Our art museums and public galleries in many cases do not organize the retrospectives that our senior artists past and present deserve, in order that we may appreciate their accomplishment and situate it intelligently within the narrative of our aesthetic cuture. This series is one way to restore the balance for at least some of our artists.”–Barry Lord, Co-President, Lord Cultural Resources, Toronto

 

“Harry and Jessie Webb’s work, a blending of abstraction with landscape, still life or figurative elements, is playful, yet very solid in composition. They echo Matisse and Picasso, who riffed off each other for decades. Their art also parallels that of other pioneering modern painters in Vancouver such as John Koerner, B.C. Binning, Don Jarvis and Lionel Thomas.”—Gregg Simpson, British Columbian artist

 

“It is too easy to dismiss historical British Columbian art as insignificant. Work created prior to the 1970s tends to be relegated to the unimportant bin. Although unknown, many artists from the late nineteenth century through to the twentieth century laid the foundations for current art to flourish. The Unheralded Artists of BC will do a great deal to change our collective amnesia.”–Letia Richardson (1943-2010), curator and writer

 

“This remarkable series on the forgotten history of visual art in what Peter Busby calls the ‘defensive, narrow-minded and cheap’ provincial backwater of the Vancouver of half a century ago is enriched by this affectionate and insightful survey of the life and work of Jack Akroyd. Akroyd’s quiet determination to cleave to his own creative principles, fashionable or not, and the constant difficulties he faced in the hardscrabble freelancer’s struggle to make a living are evocatively sketched. We are left with a touching glimpse of his corner of the world in the ‘backwater’—and a glimpse, too, of the groundwork that was being laid for the creative powerhouse the city was to become.”–Max Wyman, author, The Deﬁant Imagination: Why Culture Matters

 

“A contemporary of Vancouver artists Shadbolt and Smith, Akroyd was deeply inﬂuenced by the culture of Japan, a country that embraced his artistic vision and inspired the idiosyncratic vocabulary of images from his travels and daily life which he called ‘visual diaries.’ The Burnaby Art Gallery has long championed Akroyd’s art, and is delighted that his work is ﬁnally getting its due.”–Ellen van Eijnsbergen, Director/Curator, Burnaby Art Gallery

 

 “Busby has delved deeply into the cultural milieu of the thirty-year period during which Akroyd produced his distinctively personal oeuvre to present us with a well-researched, well-written and insightful analysis of Jack Akroyd’s art. We are reminded that our art history is written not only by the ‘big names’ of an era.”–Nicholas Tuele, art historian and consultant

 

“Mary Filer was a 20th-century prairie-born Canadian who became recognized as a professional artist both abroad and at home. Initially trained as a painter, Filer took aspects of painting, such as the layering of colour and the effect of light, and applied them three-dimensionally through the construction and lamination of various patterned and tinted shapes of cold glass. Her lifelong association with architecture and its structural inﬂuence is evident in her beautifully designed sculptural works. Painter and sculptor have merged, transforming Mary Filer into one of most innovative artists of her time.”—Richard Marcus, President of the Sculptors’ Society of British Columbia

 

“The essential purity and honest abstraction of Mary Filer’s glass sculpture developed from her early European-style training as a visual artist, and her exuberant use of colour and work with light reﬂect the Montreal inﬂuence of non-representational painterly experimentation and invention. Her importance in the Canadian and international glass art movement is monumental.”—Sylvia Tait, Canadian artist
story_txt: Introduction"... the small but mighty Mother Tongue Publishing"- Kerry Clare, Pickle Me This Canadian poet Mona Fertig has played a prominent role in the West Coast literary community for over forty years. In 1990 Mona and her husband, Renaissance man Peter Haase, moved from Vancouver to Salt Spring Island with their children and established (m)Other Tongue Press in their basement studio–first as a vibrant private press publishing gorgeous limited editions of Canadian poetry and book art, with letterpress and artwork by Peter–then evolving into a literary & art trade publisher when Mona decided it was time to bring her history and literary skills to the fore (her father was a brilliant but forgotten Vancouver artist) and shine a spotlight on the Unheralded Artists of British Columbia.The Unheralded Artists of B.C. (UABC) is an unprecedented series of beautifully designed and well-researched books, illustrating and illuminating the lives and art of previously undocumented important artists of the 1900s-1960s, (there were over 17,000 artists working in B.C. during that time). Each book is printed in full colour and contains– months of research, over 100 images, an introduction, exhibition list, endnotes and index. The books are well-written by deeply committed B.C. writers and the stories are engaging and important.Now, after nine years of hard work, amazing art sleuthing adventures; working with wonderful writers and artist’s families, great book celebrations and exhibitions, all while walking a financial tightrope, we are now reaching out for support for the publication of the next two titles, #9 and #10, in this unprecedented seriesIt is a big undertaking for a small publisher (one-woman office) to continue with such a visionary and labour intensive project without greater support. The artists featured are not famous or well-known, so it has been hard to match expenses with book sales, but that is exactly why these books are important; these artists inform the deeper narrative of our cultural history. This series is presently sustained by the passionate dedication of writers and freelance workers and self-sacrifice (Mona is the unpaid publisher) plus small grants and book sales. At Mother Tongue, quality is key, good writing and research is important and the books must be beautiful. Two titles have been finalists for the Roderick Haig-Brown Regional Prize and the Victoria Butler Book Prize, and the series can be found in better bookstores, libraries or ordered on-line from our website. Our sales are represented in North America by Heritage Group Distribution.The donations received for this campaign will give us the funds to complete production and publication of the extraordinary Life and Art of Mary Filer-UABC #9 by Christina Johnson-Dean, due out in October 2016, and help us move forward on the remarkable Life and Art of Arthur Pitts-UABC #10 by Kerry Mason, due out in October 2017.We hope you value the series and will support it and spread the word. Here are the titles we have published to date. Mona Fertig and Peter Haase at the Burnaby Art Gallery exhibition opening and book launch for The Life and Art of George Fertig : Photo Ryan Mah The Unheralded Artists of BC books:#1  The Life and Art of David Marshall by Monika Ullmann, Introduction by Brooks Joyner, 2008.#2  The Life and Art of Frank Molnar, Jack Hardman, LeRoy Jensen by Eve Lazarus, Claudia Cornwall, Wendy Newbold Patterson, Introduction by Max Wyman, Prefaces by Charles van Sandwyk, Jean Francois Guimond and Roy Patterson, 2009. #3 The Life and Art of George Fertig by Mona Fertig, Introduction by Peter Such, 2010.#4 The Life and Art of Mildred Valley Thornton by Sheryl Salloum, Foreword by Sherrill Grace. Finalist for the Roderick Haig-Brown Regional Prize, 2011.#5 The Life and Art of Ina D.D. Uhthoﬀ by Christina Johnson-Dean, Introduction by Pat Martin Bates. Victoria Butler Book Prize Finalist, 2012.#6 The Life and Art of Edythe Hembroﬀ-Schleicher by Christina Johnson-Dean, Introduction by Kerry Mason, 2013.#7 The Life and Art of Harry and Jesse Webb by Adrienne Brown, Introduction by Robert R. Reid, 2014.#8 The Life and Art of Jack Akroyd by Peter Busby, Introduction by Paul Wolf, 2015. And coming soon, with your help– OCTOBER 2016–The Life and Art of Mary Filer by Christina Johnson-Dean: Mary Filer (1920-2016), born in Edmonton, was trained as a nurse, artist and art educator lived a vibrant life in Canada, the UK and the USA, as a muralist, a painter and glass sculptor, creating dazzling work in “cold” glass art in Victoria and Vancouver. During the 1950s, Filer studied under Group of Seven artist Arthur Lismer and painter John Lyman and taught university art. Filer moved to Victoria and Vancouver in the 60s where she was on the forefront of the glass art movement. Her involvement with architects and her partnership with Harold Spence-Sales, who started the first School of Urban Planning in Canada at McGill University, led to an honourary doctorate from Simon Fraser University in 1991 and an Allied Arts Silver Medal from the Royal Architectural Institute of Canada in 1992. Major examples of her cold glass sculpture are at SFU Harbour Centre and the Vancouver General Hospital. Her work is in numerous collections, including the National Gallery of Canada, the Toronto Art Gallery, the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts and the Art Gallery of Greater Victoria. This is an important story about an often neglected genre of Canadian art history.Christina Johnson-Dean graduated from the University of California (B.A. in History, Art) and trained as a teacher. After teaching and travelling around the world, she settled in Victoria, B.C. to be near family. At the University of Victoria, she completed an MA (History in Art), serving as a teaching assistant and creating courses in local art history for Continuing Studies. Her publications include The Crease Family: A Record of Settlement and Service in British Columbia (B.C. Archives, 1981), “B.C. Women Artists 1885-1920” in British Columbia Women Artists (Art Gallery of Greater Victoria, 1985), and The Life and Art of Ina D.D. Uhthoﬀ and The Life and Art of Edythe Hembroﬀ-Schleicher (Mother Tongue Publishing, 2012, 2013).  Partial Adventures in Space 1 by Mary Filer, n.d., laminated clear, antique and shelled float glass, 14 1/2" x 22" x 13  1/2", Private Collection.Mary Filer at Dawson College, St. John, Quebec, 1946 OCTOBER 2017–The Life and Art of Arthur Pitts by Kerry Mason: Arthur Pitts (1889-1972) was born in London, UK, at the end of the Victorian age and pursued a career of art and adventure, first in South Africa, then Canada. His early fascination with indigenous cultures led him on a lifelong quest to document in vibrant watercolours, sketches and photographs what Western society perceived to be “vanishing peoples,” just as George Catlin, Paul Kane, Edward Curtis and Emily Carr had also done. Pitts also created an entire series of landscapes, portraits and architectural subjects, commercial work and hundreds of cartoons for Punch magazine. Travelling more than 4,000 miles in British Columbia and Alaska, he produced a large body of work focusing on Coast Salish, Tlingit and Ktunaxa First Nations. Pitts’ fascinating story includes life as an artist in Vancouver in the 1920s and 1930s, where he attended the Vancouver School of Decorative and Applied Arts, studying under Fred Varley, Charles Scott and J.W.G. Macdonald; WWI trench warfare and a host of “struggle and prevail” adventures. His work is in the collections of the Royal BC Museum, the Glenbow Museum and several important private collections abroad. His story and art will be revealed for the first time.Kerry Mason, B.A. M.A. is an art historian, author, curator and art consultant who lectures at the University of Victoria, University of Colorado, the Victoria College of Art and Vancouver Island School of Art, offering courses on Canada and British Columbia with a particular emphasis on Emily Carr and Indigenous Arts of the Northwest Coast. Kerry has  written many related articles, exhibit catalogues and a book, Sunlight in the Shadows: the landscape of Emily Carr, for Oxford University Press.  She has curated more than fifty exhibitions for the University of Victoria and other institutions throughout North America.Blanket of Haida Princess, circa 1930, watercolour by Arthur Pitts What We Need and Where It’s Going Expenses are high for each Unheralded Artists of BC title. We publish one title a year. The grants we receive cover some editing and design costs, but not the writer’s research; nor all the editing, which includes indexing, endnotes and multiple copyedits and proofing; and permission charges for images as well as photography. They also do not cover the publisher’s honorarium, or all printing costs ( full colour, we keep our printing in Canada) and promotion for the series, which is key for its sustainability. The writer receives a small advance, 10% of royalties on sales and a standard contract.  Here is a breakdown of expenses for UABC titles #9 and #10:Editorial/Permissions/Photography: $5,000Production and Design: $4,000Printing and Binding: $13,000Marketing: $6,000Research and Travel: $2,000Total budget for 2 UABC books: $30,000We need to raise $20,000 for our campaign, and will apply for funding for $10,000 from arts councils. If we go beyond our goal, funds will go towards further promotion of the series and to paying the publisher, Mona Fertig, an honorarium towards her living expenses, as publishing is her full time job. What You Will Receive in Return During the campaign, we will be offering 35 amazing perks! Perks are gifts and incentives you receive when you make a donation. These perks will include our beautiful published books ( fiction, poetry, art), historical art by a variety of BC artists–Jack Akroyd, Takao Tanabe, George Fertig, Jack Hardman, Irene Hoffar Reid, Marguerite Pinney, Harry & Jessie Webb, Peter Paul Ochs, Rob Steeves, Mary Filer; our signed and numbered limited editions (letterpress and bookart); time to write or just get away in our lovely cosy Seaview Retreat on Salt Spring Island; Happy Hour with us in our sun porch on Salt Spring; a selection of UABC cards or custom printed letterpressed "Thank-you' cards; and an introduction to letterpress printing workshop for two, by Peter in our letterpress printing studio. We will run our campaign for 33 days. If we reach out goal of $20,000 it will become an InDemand Campaign and people can still continue to donate and receive Perks after that date. If we do not reach our goal, we will still receive the amount raised, but the campaign will not become an InDemand Campaign. Here are our Perks. There is something for everyone!35 Gifts, one for every donation, ranging from $20 and up."Books & Cards," "Art" and "Experiences". Have a look.Also scroll down and read Praise for the UABC series F A B U L O U S    P E R K S! Other Ways You Can Help If you can’t donate to our campaign, there are other ways you can help. Share our campaign and tell others about it. Send it to friends, booklovers, artists, collectors, galleries, art lovers, historians and anyone else you know who you think might be interested. And go to our website if you want to see what other books we publish (fiction, poetry and non-fiction) http://www.mothertonguepublishing.com/Thank-you to all who donated art for the cause and thanks to Mahyar Saeedi for video production.Backers will receive regular updates on the progress of the campaign.Thanks for your support!best,Mona Fertig and Peter Haase Praise for The Unheralded Artists of BC Series: “This important book reveals David Marshall as a sculptor of certain strength whose art grew throughout his lifetime to achieve a level of simplicity and power that arise from a clear statement of form and mass with absolute fidelity to each media–wood, stone and bronze–in which he worked. He is one of a generation of late modernists who have just left us–one thinks of Chillida or Oteiza in Spain, for example–whose work will endure. His accomplishment deserves to be better known in Canada, and at its best merits recognition worldwide.”–Barry Lord, President of Lord Cultural Resources “Mother Tongue is to be congratulated for launching its timely Unheralded Artists of BC series.”-Maria Tippett, author “Mona Fertig and her series Unheralded Artists of British Columbia has made a wonderful start on filling the gaps in our art history. There are lots of the unheralded in B.C. art, and I’m hoping that this series will go on and on.” –Cheryl Siegel, former Librarian/Archivist, Vancouver Art Gallery “You are doing a great service for the cultural history of British Columbia by publishing these books, and I marvel that you can do it on such a modest budget.”–Michael J. Audain, The Audain Foundation  “Mildred Valley Thonrton’s work is a documentation of an era…. I think she should have received the Order of Canada, but she didn’t live long enough.”—Christian Corbet, artist, historian and founder of the Canadian Portrait Academy  “She (Mildred Valley Thornton) was gutsy. Her work reminds me a little of the freshness of Tom Thomson’s. She was really, really good. I hope she gets some recognition now.”—Gordon Smith, Canadian artist “In a province with thousands of wonderful unheralded artists, Mother Tongue Publishing’s project is an important beginning to what will no doubt become a really significant series of books.” –Bill Jeffries, former Director, SFU Gallery “Your father (George Fertig) was a mystic really. He had a clairvoyance of a very unusual and remarkable kind. He didn’t sell it. He didn’t advertise it. But he painted it.”—Leonard Woods, artist, teacher, writer “The Burnaby Art Gallery is delighted to be a contributing partner in the George Fertig project. As an art gallery dedicated to British Columbia’s emerging and established artists, it is with great pleasure that we are able to include one of Mother Tongue Publishing’s unheralded artists within our exhibition program. Spiritually inspired and meticulously crafted, Fertig’s paintings seek to challenge each viewer to contemplate the relationships that exist between time and space and the subjects he has chosen to represent.” —Darrin Martens; former Director/Curator Burnaby Art Gallery “Unfortunately, not all artists get recognition during their lifetime. George Fertig is a good example of a ﬁne painter whose sensible handling of both palette and perspective captured the BC landscape and who is only now being discovered. My painting of English Bay is a joy to live with and I observe the artist’s love of the subject every time I look at it.”—Uno Langmann; collector, art dealer “Artist Ina Uhthoff, like her friend Emily Carr, held a passionate desire to see a permanent gallery in Victoria where people could experience art that reflected the modern era. At mid-century when the capital city had very little art presence, she was a driving force in support of founding what would become the Art Gallery of Greater Victoria. Her role in establishing the Gallery’s permanent home and hiring its first curator/director, Colin Graham, cannot be underestimated.”—Mary Jo Hughes, former chief curator, Art Gallery of Greater Victoria “I was captured by the opening line and held fast til the last word. Christina Johnson-Dean has created a wonderfully lively, fast-moving, detailed life story of the remarkable artist Ina D.D. Uhthoff, linking her to the social and cultural worlds spanning Victoria, the Kootenays and Scotland. Johnson-Dean layers the fledgling art scene in British Columbia alongside personalities both well-known and newly rediscovered, teaching us about the times through rich and individualized voices. This beautifully illustrated, foundational study gives life to the early to mid-twentieth-century artistic scene, a period often omitted in scholarship.”—Kathryn Bridge, author, archivist and manager at the British Columbia Archives, Royal BC Museum “For a variety of reasons, the work of many competent artists has never been shown in public exhibitions or been the subject of professional critiques during their lifetimes. Fertig is redressing this lack in the beautifully designed, articulate monographs in her new series, ensuring each subject a well-deserved permanent place in the public realm.”–Ann Rosenberg, Vancouver freelance critic and curator  “Until now, Edythe Hembroff-Schleicher has been known in the broader Canadian art world only as the author of two wonderful books on Emily Carr, essential volumes in their field. With this book, we discover a Hembroff who was deeply involved in the art scene in British Columbia over a long period of time. During this involvement, she struggled through chronic illness, the Depression, World War II, earning a living, a number of relocations, several marriages and changing attitudes to women and the arts. Her work merits the study this book brings. Another significant aspect of Canadian art history revealed once again by Mother Tongue’s Unheralded Artists of BC series.”—Dennis Reid, professor, History of Art, University of Toronto, and author of A Concise History of Canadian Painting “This (David Marshall) is a significant work in the sociology of art in Canada.”–George F. Drake, retired professor of Sociology, founder of Big Rock Garden Sculpture Committee, Bellingham, USA “Thornton’s portrait collection is one of the most important historical documents of the twentieth century in Canada, particularly as it relates to the First Nations.”– Anthony Westbridge, Westbridge Fine Art Ltd. "Fertig deserves far more support than she has so far for this fascinating & noble project"-Robert Amos, artist and writer “Regional art histories are the foundational building blocks of the ever-evolving national narrative. In this regard, Mother Tongue’s new series must be enthusiastically applauded.”–Dennis Reid, professor, History of Art, University of Toronto, and author of A Concise History of Canadian Painting “Contemporary and friend of Emily Carr, pioneering BC artist, art educator, critic and journalist, Ina Uhthoff is central to the history of twentieth century art in British Columbia. Much more than a footnote in Canadian Art history.”—Susan Crean, author of The Laughing One: A Journey to Emily Carr, nominated for a Governor General’s Award in Literature. “The Webbs were among an important group of artists, poets and musicians to emerge in post-war Vancouver. We are left with a touching glimpse of his corner of the world in the ‘backwater’—and a glimpse, too, of the groundwork that was being laid for the creative powerhouse the city was to become.”–Max Wyman, author, The Deﬁant Imagination: Why Culture Matters “A contemporary of Vancouver artists Shadbolt and Smith, Akroyd was deeply inﬂuenced by the culture of Japan, a country that embraced his artistic vision and inspired the idiosyncratic vocabulary of images from his travels and daily life which he called ‘visual diaries.’ The Burnaby Art Gallery has long championed Akroyd’s art, and is delighted that his work is ﬁnally getting its due.”–Ellen van Eijnsbergen, Director/Curator, Burnaby Art Gallery  “Busby has delved deeply into the cultural milieu of the thirty-year period during which Akroyd produced his distinctively personal oeuvre to present us with a well-researched, well-written and insightful analysis of Jack Akroyd’s art. We are reminded that our art history is written not only by the ‘big names’ of an era.”–Nicholas Tuele, art historian and consultant “Mary Filer was a 20th-century prairie-born Canadian who became recognized as a professional artist both abroad and at home. Initially trained as a painter, Filer took aspects of painting, such as the layering of colour and the effect of light, and applied them three-dimensionally through the construction and lamination of various patterned and tinted shapes of cold glass. Her lifelong association with architecture and its structural inﬂuence is evident in her beautifully designed sculptural works. Painter and sculptor have merged, transforming Mary Filer into one of most innovative artists of her time.”—Richard Marcus, President of the Sculptors’ Society of British Columbia “The essential purity and honest abstraction of Mary Filer’s glass sculpture developed from her early European-style training as a visual artist, and her exuberant use of colour and work with light reﬂect the Montreal inﬂuence of non-representational painterly experimentation and invention.
