There will be one removable element that will be taken out before the burning of the shrines to be added to our Phamily's collection of regional project participation. The Shrine of Brotherly Love debuted at PEX Summer Fest in Center Camp. Our PEX Phamily contributed their messages in our bottles which will come with us on our pilgrimage to the desert. When our Shrine is installed on playa we welcome the public to interact and contribute their own messages in our bottles to be burned with the Man. Our Shrine will be placed on the 9:00 side of the Man Pavilion. Please consider supporting our radical ritual through contributing to our campaign and spreading the love.  Funds raised will be used to assist in covering project transportation costs and material embellishments such as lighting specific for use at Burning Man highlighting the details of the Shrine.  Once all project costs are covered any excess funds available will assist the support camp.  We are grateful for your continued support of the Philly Burners regional projects!  Burn baby burn!  )'( ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Meet our Artists:Here's a few stories from some of the Philadelphia Shrine Artists sharing the intimate details behind what inspired their contributions...  - Mischa Greenberg and Melissa Bottiglio created a box for our Burning Man Shrine of Brotherly Love. Before designing our piece, we talked about the radical ritual (this year's Burning Man theme) surrounding capitalism, commercialism, and the almighty dollar. We built a shrine to the dollar, and included a couple other items that represent popular commercialism (Mickey Mouse, and the auto/oil industry) with Barbie-like figures bowing/yoga posing while worshiping the shrine... within a shrine. For the background, we tiled our rendition of Matisse's "Dancers," which is a piece that can be seen at The Barnes Museum, representing Philadelphia. We also like the juxtaposition of the figures freedom, dancing, being in the moment vs. the money-worshipers, being controlled by materialism. We hope you enjoy our contribution as much as we enjoyed creating it. XO  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~- Becca Johnson's story behind the "Fairmount Park" box (the one with the copper wire wrap "tree"): We sit and watch the sunset from Lemon Hill, climbing trees and watching the city descend into darkness. You can catch a cool breeze and see the water from there. It's been 9 years that I have lived in this city and the escape that Lemon Hill gives me from the concrete hustle and bustle can't be found anywhere else in the city of Brotherly Love. This kind of love is special as it unites two completely separate environments. On one side of the hill, you can see sloping green, trees climbing into the skyline and birds chirping. The other side the hill rolls down to the waterfront and is met by many lines of cars and people who are eager to start or end their day at the park. It's a  feeling of meditative quietness and solitude as you lay in the grass and another feeling that you're never quite alone when living in the city, a comfort in the loud noises that lulls you to sleep each night.  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~- By Kim Traub: Ben Franklin said, "As we enjoy great advantages from the inventions of others, we should be glad of an opportunity to serve others by any invention of ours, and this we should do freely and generously." Ben Franklin would have been an excellent Burner.To many Philadelphians, Ben Franklin is the ultimate Founding Father. His legend is familiar to most Americans as a self made, inventive Renaissance man with a hearty lust for life. The Shrine box I created for him was inspired by one of the oldest museums in the United States, the Franklin Institute; "...The Franklin Institute has played a central, yet constantly evolving, role in meeting the educational needs of America in the fields of science and technology. For the organization's first century, the Institute offered classes in mechanics, drafting, and engineering, and promoted science and invention." (https://www.fi.edu/about-us/mission-history)The Benjamin Franklin National Memorial is a 20 foot high statue of Franklin located in the entry to The Institute. Of course, Ben is well known for many of his inventions, especially electricity and his famous kite and key experiment. He was a ravenous reader with a home filled with books an he invented bifocals so he could continue reading as he aged. His "bookish inclination" inspired him to become an accomplished printer and he started the first U.S. public library.  Poor Richard was a pseudonym he used to publish quotable wit and wisdom in the 1700s. One of the center piece exhibits in the Franklin Institute and favorite of school field trips in the Philadelphia area is the walk through anatomical heart complete with beating soundtrack. "The doors to wisdom are never shut."Other symbols in my shrine box:Brotherly love was also immortalized in Robert Indiana's "LOVE" statue, a park centerpiece and bookend to the Ben Franklin Parkway (the other end is the Philadelphia Museum of Art.) The Parkway is also home to the Rodin Museum, the largest collection of August Rodin's sculptures outside of Paris. His most famous work, The Thinker, is an appropriate figure to pair with Ben Franklin's desire for knowledge. "An investment in knowledge pays the best interest." ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Tim Ahern and Nicole Russo: We made our little box in order pay homage to some things that we celebrate every day; colors shapes and sizes. Bright colors are one of our favorite ways of expressing ourselves. We are bright and colorful people! Different colored and sized spheres are glued together to form new constructs. They are meant to be reminiscent of the fact that even though we are all a bit different, if we come together we can make something new and beautiful. And it’s pretty awesome that they look like colorful boobs. We like boobs. Alot. There are also things that we only unveil to the most curious. Perhaps, if the sun has set and the stars are out you should look a little closer at our multicolored representation of some of the things that we are thankful for and see what you can find.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Jen Grace: Orpheus, the saddest robot,is walking in front of boathouse row like a #boss. This is a 221 piece robot I built...he is a music box and he lights up at night! He is my celebration of impermeance and understanding that it's okay to let go of things you've worked hard on. Even if it is beautiful and was your world for a moment in time.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Read more about the Man Pavilion Shrine projects here:https://burningman.org/event/brc/2017-shrines-and-processionals/~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Shrine of Brotherly Love at PEX FestPhotos credit: Red Lite Photos

story:
Short Summary

Hi there, I'm Eman, a freelancer creative graphics designer. I have a small dream which is build a small graphic design workshop. I made this campaign for helping me to buy a graphics hardware and a new laptop for me by funding me with money. Your contribution will help me very much because i need to improve my work but my laptop is very old fashion and very very slow and this don't help me anymore.
Please visit my Behance account and review my work: behance.net/EmanFawzyM

Full Story

I am Eman a freelancer creative graphic designer and content creator. I studied a graphic design and marketing self study by myself. I merged between Art and marketing to output a very powerful piece of art which can attract the eyes.

I worked with a lot of brands and companies as a freelancer to make sure that I really talented and can create a creative pieces of art. You can view my work from here: behance.net/EmanFawzyM
I can work on adobe Photoshop,adobe illustrator,adobe after effect,adobe premier and blender

I want to improve my work and build my small graphic design workshop and output more powerful pieces of art with higher quality by buying a new hardware like wacomgraphics tablet and new desktop because mine is very very slow and old fashion and can't work in 3D tasks it crashing all the time. So, I want you to fund me to buy a new hardware to help me in my work.
My Problem and What I need:

My laptop is very slow and old fashion, it doesn't help me to work in a graphics tasks specially in 3D designs. And I want to build my small graphic design workshop. unfortunately my current laptop doesn't help me to output higher quality of my work and it doesn't work in 3D graphics it crashed all the time.
I want you to fund me to buy a new hardware to improve my work and build my workshop.
Other Ways You Can Help

please share my Campaign on your accounts.
If you want to hire me as a freelancer, visit this link
www.freelancer.com/u/EmanElmasry.html
If you want to share my work please share this link :
www.behance.net/EmanFawzyM
Thank you.

story:
Four years ago we built a festival with strong focus on electronic music and visuals, in a way, exploring a new kind of sensibility. We found the perfect space to make it happen: A castle in Portugal with all of its magic and history. Inside the walls, the perfect scenario for a complete immersive environment.

FESTIVAL FORTE IS SCHEDULED FOR AUGUST 30 - 2 SEPTEMBER 2018

Then, we decided to invite artists that share the same passion as we do, capable of doing spectacular audiovisual shows. Since then, the Forte has become a place of wonder, with people coming from all over the world to witness things that they have never seen before, bewildered with awe. The bar has been set very high as everyone needs to excel and surpass their own limits to become part of it.Quality, spectacularity, education, comfort need to be the main factors of success, we thought. But then we learned that we are in a context that has its own rules. Every artist now has a price tag which depends on the amount of people that he can attract, so if you want to do it the easy way then you only need to invite the big names. The ones that at the end will bring profit to the event. As a result we see that nearly every main electronic music festival in the world presents the same headliners. People travel countries and continents to see more of the same over and over again. This policy lead to a market wise scenario. A business just like any other. But what about the art? And those artists that have lower price tags and never get a chance to have the spotlight that they deserve? Consequences of capitalism, however we believe in Heart over Money and Art over Industry.

We’ve done everything right. The interaction between the crowd of Festival Forte and the locals is emotive, with strong ties. Every year, these people look forward to meet again as if they were a family. Some foreigners already have their beds prepared for them by a sweet old lady from the village.

Apart from preserving the castle with a lot of preventive measures, we also contribute and finance the reconstruction of heritage structures, such as the portico of the Church that is inside.

The government has recognized the festival’s efforts for sustainability, funding  these types of initiatives, such as a cashless system, reusable cups, compost toilets, digital ads - no printing!.

- Casey Reas Installation at The Glass House -

Festival Forte is also present in universities organizing lectures to share scientific knowledge about creative coding. Together with teachers, we have internships. Scientists, musicians, producers, experts are all involved in the making.

The Camping site is definitely one of highlights of the Festival, having its own charisma. It is walking distance from the castle and all infrastructures are reinforced providing exceptional conditions for comfort and dynamism in a plural context including art, gastronomy and music.

It is free for everyone who purchases tickets for the festival and is definitely the place to be during the day, while the castle is closed.

We employed huge effort in generative art to provide a soul that  is visible through sound, visuals, design, technology and nature. Great art allows people to communicate across differences, converging values and principles of solidarity, experience and expertise.

- Jaygo Bloom Installation at the Generative Garden - 

There are no limits to the spectacularity that we want to reach and even challenge artists to prepare very special and complicated performances such as the premiere of Robert Henke's Lumiere II laser show for the first time in an open air environment. Lydia Lunch has also presented the only performance of the year of her audiovisual project “Medusa’s bed”. Front 242 made the complete stage show, bridging the past with the future. Cabaret Voltaire also made one of its few appearances of the year at Festival Forte. The same with In Aeternam Vale. Mythical names such as Jeff Mills have played in the castle and a lot of other artists that are definitely part of the new generation of groundbreaking music, such as Adam X, Adriana Lopez, Ben Klock, Blawan, Byetone,  Clark, Donato Dozzy, DVS1,  Kangding Ray, Lucy, Minilogue, Mathew Jonson, Nathan Fake, Ninos du Brasil, Oscar Mulero, Phase Fatale, Peder Mannerfelt, Rødhåd, Ron Morelli, Shifted, Shlømo, Surgeon, T. Raumschmiere, Varg and Vatican Shadow.

Organizing a big event that does not comply with the mainstream is extremely hard, but possible. We did it four times. With the support of a very special crowd of believers eager to be filled with the rich content that is provided, it can be done. To keep everything pure, not sell out and follow our principles we never go through the routes of commercialism to finance the project. Instead we rely completely on ticket sales.Now we have been forced to stall at a point where we cannot advance further without your support. Nearly all expenses of the future edition need to be paid up front and we also have debts to solve. We all love Festival Forte but we need money to make our dreams work in this materialistic world. This is why we are reaching out to you. Festival Forte 2018 can only happen with your contribution.

Make your mark and stay solid, Together we can make this happen. If there is no room for Festival Forte in this moment in time, we should all be sad because it means that there is no place for pure art anymore. Just emptiness. If we make it work however, we will let the world know that there are at least 5000 people that defy the standards, who think broadly and put the essence of art back into play.

You don’t need to come to Festival Forte to be part of it. You only need to feel the same way that we do and be proud to contribute for such a noble cause. Also, if you purchase a ticket and decide not to go you can then sell it easily on ticketswap.com.

This is the moment of truth. Time to act. Prove that Art really matters.

Visit festivalforte.com 

"(...) you can’t argue that Festival Forte is not just a music festival, it’s a festival of the arts, sitting in a location that you can hardly best, it’s an event to be lived at all senses." - Wide Future

"If Festival Forte continues to commit to these principles, then next year can only be even more of a success." Resident advisor

"As an example of a festival that believes in its acts, its venue and its crowd, Forte is hard to beat." -. Crack

"Montemor-O-Velho, magnifique forteresse au Portugal construite au Moyen Âge accueillait fin août une superbe affiche" - Trax

"Nuevamente, nuestros vecinos portugueses se coronan como gente que de verdad sabe hacer las cosas y cree por encima de todo en la influencia, el arte y la cultura que conlleva esta música." - Vicious

"En cette fin d’août, nous avons fini par débarquer dans cette mignonne petite bourgade située entre Porto et Lisbonne, du nom de Montemor-o-Vello. Ce joli patelin aux ruelles médiévales dominé par son immense château du XIV siècle que nous ne pouvions pas louper." - Electro News

"Una nueva demostración de que Festival Forte es un valor seguro a la hora de elegir pasar unos días cerca de la costa portuguesa combinándolos con música electrónica de muchos kilates." - Growsoundmag

"You can’t argue that Festival Forte is not just a music festival, it’s a festival of the arts, sitting in a location that you can hardly best, it’s an event to be lived at all senses" - Wide Future

"O FORTE é um dos melhores festivais de electrónica do país, com uma programação ímpar, que decerto agradou a todos os que gostam da repetição e do ritmo como ingredientes indispensáveis na música que ouvem." - Ritmos e Batidas

"Festival Forte, an electronic music festival, is set in some incredible surroundings. In a small village just outside of Coimbra, there is a huge castle set upon a hill, overlooking the village. Castelo Montemor-O-Velho is the castle in which this incredible Festival takes place." - 55 Secrets

More reviews here: http://www.festivalforte.com/festival-forte/reviews/

 

If Festival Forte does not go ahead will I get a full refund?

Of course. Indiegogo will retain your contribution until the campaign is over. Then if we decide to go on, the funds will be transferred to us and you will receive your perk(s), otherwise, Indiegogo will immediately refund you right after this time has expired.

When does the campaign end?

The campaign ends on January 14.

What happens if I claim a ticket and then decide not to come?

You can easily sell it later on ticketswap.com

How many tickets are there to sell?

Given the limitation of the castle walls, capacity is limited to 5000 people per day.

What if I buy a lifetime ticket and the Festival ceases from existing?

If we make it to next year then we will surely have a Festival for many years to come.

What happens after I make a donation?

You will be a Backer and be part of the process of the making of Festival Forte 2018, by sharing your opinions with the community. You will also have first access to all sorts of news regarding the confirmed artists and other developments.

I am portuguese and do not have a credit card. How can I help?

You can easily use your debit card with MBNET. On their site you have detailed instructions on how to do it.

I have claimed a Christmas Perk Deluxe. How can I choose the record collection ?

You can select them from the vinyls and cds that are available on sonicgoods.com

 

- Jaygo Bloom Installation at the Generative Chapel -

On every edition of Festival Forte, an EP was released on Soniculture label. Here, you can listen to a playlist with all of the tracks:

https://soundcloud.com/festivalforte/sets/festival-forte-music

story:
We are based in Jerusalem, the isolated capital of an occupied country, where disempowerment is used as a tool of displacement. Palestinians here face unlawful arrests, land confiscations and home demolitions while lacking proper economic development, infrastructure building and sufficient education and health systems. It's all a part of Israel's plans for Jerusalem: to keep a “demographic balance” of 70% Israeli and 30% Palestinian.

At Grassroots Jerusalem, we contribute to the creation of a long-term Palestinian strategy for Jerusalem by amplifying the voices of Palestinian communities so that they set the agenda for the city, not the international community. For the last 5 years, we’ve been providing tools for Jerusalemites to share their vision for Jerusalem. We create maps, give tours, run an online platform, and host events and workshops at our hub: "al-Marsa" (The Harbour).

Until now, Grassroots Jerusalem has received financial support mainly through project based, short-term and top down frameworks (except for our first core-funding grant). No relevant, efficient and lasting work can be concretely implemented with such limitations. Through our work with Palestinian communities and grassroots organisations, we have discovered that they share the same experience with international aid.

Since the Oslo agreement, the world through international aid has supported the imported “peace process." This international aid primarily designs, coordinates and implements actions as if Palestine was a humanitarian crisis, a 67 year old emergency humanitarian crisis! Most of the civil services are provided by these unrepresentative entities to help the Palestinians merely survive under this occupation. While Palestinians expect the international community to focus on ending the occupation, this approach stifles the genuine grassroots movement organising to resist it.

Development and advocacy in Jerusalem are dependent on international NGO (INGO) and UN humanitarian support. However, current programmes perpetuate the notion that the Israeli occupation of Palestine is a humanitarian disaster. They provide aid which helps Palestinians “survive under occupation,” not end it, which normalises military occupation and economic colonisation. This perception has kept long-term development stifled while granting consecutive Israeli governments carte blanche to develop mass settlements and neglect obligations to international law and occupied Jerusalem residents. 

Palestinians expected the international community to support their struggle to end the occupation and ensure freedom and dignity. Instead, short-term projects using top-down frameworks, have prevented Palestinian leadership from strategising in sustainable ways and perpetuated the need for humanitarian aid. This cycle has created an “INGO industrial complex” that has become a rampant problem in the global South. It makes Palestinian civil society and grassroots leadership dependent on short term funding cycles for programmes with no coordinated vision that are authorised by international staff who are neither elected nor permanent residents of the city. The INGOisation of the occupation unintentionally draws the attention away from the real problem (occupation!) with increasingly privatised systems. It should be called what it is in the bigger picture: Benevolent Colonialism.

By implementing project-based, short-term plans and acting without accountability to the local community, the INGO industrial complex disempowers Palestinian leadership and organisations and inhibits the development of grassroots movements, long-term visions, and political change. Beyond the failure of the current model to effect systemic change, this model has spawned the unintended consequence of fostering a widespread, cynical soul and destroying independent initiative. It has cultivated a reliance on and expectation of the perpetuation of this type of outside assistance. In order to sustain our work, we must break from this limiting system of international aid by imagining alternative methods of sustainable funding. 


In the past, we have been forced to rely on short-term project-based grants fundamentally inconsistent with the needs of the Palestinian community and our organization's vision.  If an authentic and sustainable change to the oppressive staus quo is to come, this must change. Your support today will plant the seeds of this future.  We know we can't rely on you alone for support, but it will enable us to invest in diversified revenue streams that can sustain us into the future and serve as a model to our many grassroots partners.


The money we raise will be used to publish the second edition of Wujood (our political tourist guide book on Jerusalem), complete our mapping project by publishing a comprehensive Jerusalem atlas, and train more Jerusalemite guides in order to expand our tours. 


Here's where you come in. We know you don't want to give us money and then have us come back around asking for more all the time. That's why we're asking you to dig a little deeper just this one time and help us speed toward economic independence.
story_txt:
We are based in Jerusalem, the isolated capital of an occupied country, where disempowerment is used as a tool of displacement. Palestinians here face unlawful arrests, land confiscations and home demolitions while lacking proper economic development, infrastructure building and sufficient education and health systems. It's all a part of Israel's plans for Jerusalem: to keep a “demographic balance” of 70% Israeli and 30% Palestinian.At Grassroots Jerusalem, we contribute to the creation of a long-term Palestinian strategy for Jerusalem by amplifying the voices of Palestinian communities so that they set the agenda for the city, not the international community. For the last 5 years, we’ve been providing tools for Jerusalemites to share their vision for Jerusalem. We create maps, give tours, run an online platform, and host events and workshops at our hub: "al-Marsa" (The Harbour).


Until now, Grassroots Jerusalem has received financial support mainly through project based, short-term and top down frameworks (except for our first core-funding grant). No relevant, efficient and lasting work can be concretely implemented with such limitations. Through our work with Palestinian communities and grassroots organisations, we have discovered that they share the same experience with international aid.Since the Oslo agreement, the world through international aid has supported the imported “peace process." This international aid primarily designs, coordinates and implements actions as if Palestine was a humanitarian crisis, a 67 year old emergency humanitarian crisis! Most of the civil services are provided by these unrepresentative entities to help the Palestinians merely survive under this occupation. While Palestinians expect the international community to focus on ending the occupation, this approach stifles the genuine grassroots movement organising to resist it.

Development and advocacy in Jerusalem are dependent on international NGO (INGO) and UN humanitarian support. However, current programmes perpetuate the notion that the Israeli occupation of Palestine is a humanitarian disaster. They provide aid which helps Palestinians “survive under occupation,” not end it, which normalises military occupation and economic colonisation. This perception has kept long-term development stifled while granting consecutive Israeli governments carte blanche to develop mass settlements and neglect obligations to international law and occupied Jerusalem residents. 
Palestinians expected the international community to support their struggle to end the occupation and ensure freedom and dignity. Instead, short-term projects using top-down frameworks, have prevented Palestinian leadership from strategising in sustainable ways and perpetuated the need for humanitarian aid. This cycle has created an “INGO industrial complex” that has become a rampant problem in the global South. It makes Palestinian civil society and grassroots leadership dependent on short term funding cycles for programmes with no coordinated vision that are authorised by international staff who are neither elected nor permanent residents of the city. The INGOisation of the occupation unintentionally draws the attention away from the real problem (occupation!) with increasingly privatised systems. It should be called what it is in the bigger picture: Benevolent Colonialism.
By implementing project-based, short-term plans and acting without accountability to the local community, the INGO industrial complex disempowers Palestinian leadership and organisations and inhibits the development of grassroots movements, long-term visions, and political change. Beyond the failure of the current model to effect systemic change, this model has spawned the unintended consequence of fostering a widespread, cynical soul and destroying independent initiative. It has cultivated a reliance on and expectation of the perpetuation of this type of outside assistance. In order to sustain our work, we must break from this limiting system of international aid by imagining alternative methods of sustainable funding. 

In the past, we have been forced to rely on short-term project-based grants fundamentally inconsistent with the needs of the Palestinian community and our organization's vision.  If an authentic and sustainable change to the oppressive staus quo is to come, this must change. Your support today will plant the seeds of this future.  We know we can't rely on you alone for support, but it will enable us to invest in diversified revenue streams that can sustain us into the future and serve as a model to our many grassroots partners.

The money we raise will be used to publish the second edition of Wujood (our political tourist guide book on Jerusalem), complete our mapping project by publishing a comprehensive Jerusalem atlas, and train more Jerusalemite guides in order to expand our tours. 

Here's where you come in. We know you don't want to give us money and then have us come back around asking for more all the time. That's why we're asking you to dig a little deeper just this one time and help us speed toward economic independence.

story:
Introduction

Erin Bassett is an artist based in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Her artistic journey began with painting lessons in her grandmother’s garage at the age of 5, the gift of a camera at the age of 18 and the discovery of fabric at 28. She now has her own company, Erin Bassett Artistry, which aims to create unique, sophisticated, one-of-a-kind textiles and fabric sculptures for the home and body. Her inspiration comes from her fascination with the characteristics of silk and the beautiful seascapes of the local Florida reefs. Erin designs, sculpts, and creates artistic wall art and wearable silk accessories. She has been an exhibiting artist since 2002 after graduating from the University of Florida with a BFA in Creative Photography and continued through her studies at the Savannah College of Art + Design, where she received her MFA in Textile Design in 2012.  Her work was discovered this year by a scout and now she is on her way to exhibit at Spectrum Miami during Art Basel! 

This campaign is raising money to get Erin to Spectrum during Art Basel. Art Basel is an international art fair with three shows staged annually in Basel, Switzerland; Miami Beach, Florida; and Hong Kong. Each show is organized into sectors which showcase contemporary artworks by established and newly emerging artists. Over 250 of the world’s leading galleries participate drawing over 70,000 visitors each year, offering an exciting and inspiring week for artists, collectors, curators, critics and art enthusiasts.

This is the opportunity to make a career out of passion and talent. Art Basel is where dreams become reality. Becoming an artist has been a life long dream… but it is not a cheap dream. In order to create large and impactful work that will make an impression on galleries, journalists and collectors, Erin must first purchase the supplies to create the work, take 5 months to make it, and coordinate the logistics to create the best exhibit possible. Raising money will allow Erin can concentrate on the work itself to make the best impression on the art industry as possible as a jump start to her career.

The Breakdown

  • Supplies to make the work: Fabric (and lots of it), canvases, dyes, stiffener, objects, rubber bands, rubber gloves, needles, thread, etc etc etc...
  • Show materials: Professional photographs of each piece, printed catalog, business cards and vinyl display for the wall.
  • Transportation and logistics: hotel, trailer, custom boxes for each piece (extra large cardboard boxes are crazy expensive!), gas. 

Since I have never done a show on this grand a scale, I need to update not only the work itself but the way I display the work and the packaging for the clients who purchase it!

Perks:

  • Spectrum/Red Dot tickets to the Show!
  • Signed postcard artwork
  • Lapel pin
  • Necklace
  • Signed catalog from the show
  • 2 hour Dinner with the Artist
  • 4 hour Workshop with the artist

Any funds donated will go towards the cost of making the artwork that will be displayed at Spectrum. Even if the entire goal is not met, any and all donations will get the artist closer to success.

The Impact

Art Basel is an international art fair. Boasting over 160 exhibitors from all over the world, Spectrum showcases thousands of cutting-edge works of art in its sleek, gallery-style venue in Miami’s Arts and Entertainment District. Last year’s VIP Opening Night Party drew a crowd of 5,800 to take part in exciting unveilings, refreshments, and a first glimpse at all of the artwork. Throughout the weekend, throngs of visitors enjoy Meet the Artist events, live demos, inspiring Art Labs, and the palpable Miami Art Week buzz in the air.

Over the past decade, my work has awed and impressed most spectators. Every time the work has been on display I get comments like “you should show this at Art Basel” or “This work needs to be seen by more people”. Well, this is my chance to show it to the art world on a grand scale. By Exhibiting during Art Basel, I will get exposure to galleries, collectors and journalists. This is the kind of event that can turn childhood dreams into a lifelong, sustainable career. 

There is never just “one” shot. If you fail, you simply try again but his opportunity is a big one for me. If Spectrum in December is successful, there is an opportunity to show at ArtExpo in New York in April, building on the momentum gained at Spectrum. 

The Challenge

One of the hardest parts about becoming an artist is getting the opportunity to present your work to the key players: gallerists, collectors and journalists. These are the people that tell the world which artists to pay attention to. After a 20 year struggle, Erin has worked incredibly hard to overcome the obstacles associated with a career in art. Spectrum provides the opportunity to get her artwork in front of the art world on a national and international level.

In order to make an impact on the key players that will be walking the halls of Spectrum, Erin must create dynamic, large, and intricate works. This will take money to buy supplies, the time and skill it takes to create the work as well as a beautifully clean, crisp display inside the booth. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I hope that you consider making a contribution. Every dollar counts in the journey to Spectrum. If you cannot contribute monetarily at this time, please consider sharing this campaign with your friends and family. Thank you in advance from the bottom of my heart!

story:
Summary

The Unsolicited Sideshow is a pop-up exhibition and event series that explores how the contemporary condition of ‘otherness’ informs architectural expression. It opens at the Chicago Athletic Association (CAA) as a corollary exhibit to the 2017 Chicago Architecture Biennial’s main stage at the Chicago Cultural Center. Like the parallel tents of entertainment that congregate around a traveling circus, The Sideshow positions a cast of architectural 'freaks' and 'weirdos' to amplify the energy and visitorship of the main attraction, and give voice to a younger generation of thinkers and practitioners. Drawing on its history of nomadic entertainment, the pop-up content will activate the lobby and mezzanine of the CAA, displayed on a collection of custom sandwich boards (Sideshow Boards) designed as abstracted sideshow characters.

Alongside the exhibition, the Sideshow will culminate in four Friday night events, called Tank Takeovers. The “Tank" is a large exhibition hall inside the CAA. These one-night happenings will activate the Tank’s double-height space, highlight select contributors from the pop-up content in the lobby, and explore thematic cues that engage ideas of ‘otherness.’ Tank Takeovers will initiate dialogue between the Sideshow and the Biennial and the Chicago community through performance, installation, panel discussions, and multi-media presentations.

The exhibition and Tank Takeovers will engage the contemporary discourse of architecture, as well as contemporary culture and politics by asking contributors to explore ideas of 'otherness,' abnormality, and taboo. In the current political and cultural moment, hard lines are being drawn to define and reward ideas of normalcy by spotlighting and punishing an expanding profile of 'others.' Just as the circus sideshow challenged the bounds of normalcy, The Sideshow will explore the contemporary condition of 'otherness' as it informs architectural expression through form, program, material, and affect.

The Unsolicited Sideshow at the Chicago Architecture Biennial is curated and produced by Could Be Architecture (Joseph Altshuler & Zack Morrison), curator and critic Chelsea Ross, and designer Matthew Harlan. We will present architectural pleasures, oddities, and delights from a troupe of young and emerging designers and practices.

The contributors hail from far and wide, with an emphasis on Chicago and Midwest. Contributors include Adrianne Joergensen (Singapore), Architecture Hero (Chicago), Chicago Underground Practice (Chicago), Cosmo Design Factory (Philmont, NY), Could Be Architecture (Chicago), John Clark & Taylor Holloway (Chicago), Office Andorus (Portland), office ca (Columbus, OH), S. Surface (Seattle), Skylar Moran (Chicago), SUBSTUDIO (Detroit and Cincinnati), and Team B Architecture & Design (Cincinnati).

Serious frivolity and terrifying joy await you at the Sideshow!

What We Need

As an independent endeavor and a labor of love, we need your support to fund the exhibit design, production, and programming.

Every dollar matters. While the first priority of our campaign is to fund the design and fabrication of the Sideshow Boards themselves, reaching our full fundraising goal will allow us to augment the scope of the monthly Friday night events, print an exhibition catalogue that will elaborate on each contributor’s work, and support the contributors’ time with artist honoraria.

Help us exhibit architectural ‘otherness’ to a broad public and offer free architectural and cultural programming in an informal and approachable setting in downtown Chicago!

Your support will help fund the following:
$3000 for Exhibition Supplies (wood, paint, tools etc...) 
$2500 for Tank Takeovers (performers, bartenders, production, and marketing)
$2000 for Exhibition Catalogue (design and printing)
$2500 for Contributor Honoraria  

The Impact

Chicago is a city celebrated for its bold architecture, yet many of its denizens lack accessible and entertaining opportunities to engage with the city’s architectural legacy and future. The Unsolicited Sideshow provides a “ticket” to an architectural show that invites a broad public into an expansive world of Chicago-infused architectural ideas.

In addition, we believe that quasi-public spaces should be activated with engaging content for everyone to enjoy. Many hotel and office lobbies in the loop are open to public passersby, and we see these spaces as fertile territory to organize intentional, educational, and entertaining content for the public. The Sideshow will do just that within the ground-floor lobby, mezzanine, and Tank spaces at the Chicago Athletic Association.

Finally, we believe that architecture is much more than just buildings—architecture is a cultural body of ideas about space, form, material, and program that informs how we inhabit a city. The Sideshow’s monthly Friday night events will partner with exhibition contributors, artists, and cultural producers working outside of architecture to produce dynamic programming. This will instigate conversations across Chicago’s cultural landscape, and will draw audiences from multiple cultural and creative enclaves to explore and celebrate ideas of otherness in our communities.

Risks & Challenges

The Sideshow’s biggest obstacle is simple financing. We have a stellar curatorial team, support from the Chicago Athletic Association and the Chicago Architecture Biennial for space and marketing, and a ready roster of talented contributors. All we need is a few (thousand) dollars to bring the show to life.

In addition to the generous support we receive from this campaign, we are applying for supplementary grants, and donating our own time and resources to ensure the exhibition’s success.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this Indiegogo campaign with your friends and via social media and direct email. Thank you in advance for spreading the word to your personal networks!

story:
The Dumpster Project Creator-in-Residence No. 1: Bernadette Noll

What is The Dumpster Project?

The Dumpster Project’s goal is to turn a used 6’x6’ trash receptacle into a high-tech, sustainable, healthy, and beautiful microhome. Our project is collaborative, somewhat open-ended, and best of all, wildly engaging. The Dumpster Project has become many things: a re-imagining of home, a portable community learning tool, the means to a lively sustainability conversation, an innovative STEM education platform, and the anchor of a wider set of green campus initiatives at Huston-Tillotson University (HT), a historically black institution located in the heart of east Austin, Texas. Now we are inviting artists to reflect on the Dumpster-to-home transformation and create work that broadens our collective view of sustainability.

We've learned that the challenge of transforming a trash dumpster into a tiny sustainable home inspires creative problem solving. We’ve seen second graders imagine bike-powered appliances, green builders envision heat-storing wax walls, and activists discuss “dumpster footprints” as an environmental impact measure. Now we invite even broader forms of thought-provoking experimentation with our Creative-in-Residence program. We're inviting artists and creators of all types to take on the dumpster challenge and re-envision some aspect of the project as we investigate the impacts of modern life.


Our First Creative-in-Residence

We are fundraising for our very first creative-in-residence, Bernadette Noll.  She’s an author, maker, and craft coordinator of Austin’s Mini Maker Faire. When Bernadette learned that we wanted to insulate the dumpster with natural materials, she immediately brainstormed ways to use reclaimed fabric. She decided on wool, which is a good insulator and improves air quality - a plus in our very small space. Bernadette designed and created a vibrant insulating wall panel from reclaimed wool that depicts the core Dumpster Project values of sustainability, home, and experimentation. It is beautiful and practical and represents everything the Dumpster Project is about – transforming a space into something good for you and for the environment.

Joining Bernadette in forging the way for our new Creative-in-Residence program is Christine Giordano. She’s been documenting Bernadette’s project and generally being awesome. She is a producer and art director of television, film, and commercials.  She got her start interning on the award-winning documentary series FRONTLINE, and has recently served as Story Producer for RFD-TV's cowboy reality show All Around Performance Horse.  Christine has created online commercial content for brands such as Macy's, Verizon Wireless, and L'Oreal, and also directs digital shorts for the sketch comedy group GROOVY PARTY.  When she's not on set she is tending to her eleven chickens, twenty-thousand bees, and coordinating Austin's weekly ladies-only dance phenomenon, Dance Dance Party Party.

Why a Dumpster?

We get asked this a lot. If we want to build a sustainable home as a teaching and learning experiment, why don't we just use a shipping container or build a small eco-friendly home from scratch? There are two big reasons we use a tiny dumpster. The first has to do with exactly that, size. The dumpster is small! It has a 6’ by 6’ footprint on the ground and the interior square footage is about 36 square feet. This makes our task more challenging and pushes us to really innovate and rethink.

The second reason is that dumpsters are symbols of, and receptacles for, waste. Many times, we throw trash into the dumpster and rarely consider where it goes after that, or what sort of impact we are having on the planet as a result. A big goal of the Dumpster Project is to raise awareness by making these invisible processes that affect us and the planet very tangible...say by transforming that very same magic waste-disappearing box into a home where every environmental repercussion is very apparent.

What this Campaign Will Pay For

This campaign will launch the Dumpster Project Creative-in-Residence Program. Proceeds will be split evenly among Bernadette, Christine, and the Dumpster Project non-profit organization. This will pay Bernadette and Christine for their time and work and cover the cost of materials used for Bernadette’s dumpster-inspired insulating wool wall hanging. Christine’s photos and videos will help us continue to use the dumpster as a platform to inspire and educate. The Dumpster Project share of the proceeds will cover operation costs, including staff and materials for the continuing dumpster transformation as well as costs of launching this new creative program.

Rewards!

There are awesome perks for donating, like an invitation to our super-cool dumpster party or our Dumpster Project craft night at Recycled Reads.  We’ve got Dumpster schwag like our “Yes we can!” t-shirts, tote bags, a brand new “Wish you were here” postcard, and a very few, super limited-edition dumpster cacti (made from recycled dumpsters).

For our supporters in Austin or nearby, we also want to meet you and inspire your creativity. Bernadette is offering two craft nights for you and your friends. Using all reclaimed/recycled/re-sourced materials she will bring supplies for a totally cool utilitarian craft project. This ain’t no egg carton art. We'll hand stitch sweet felted wool wallets to protect your phone or hold your precious cards and cash. For humans of all skill levels, this project is good for beginners and expert stitchers.

If you just want to experience the Dumpster, you can book an evening for yourself in two ways. Upon successful completion of this campaign, we’ll want to celebrate, so we will be hosting a super-cool party for backers at our Partaaay level, or you can host your own Dumpster-themed date night or small event.

Your Impact

Your support of the Dumpster Project allows us to continue our mission to educate, inspire, and innovate as we transform a dumpster into a happy healthy home. We have brought our sustainability message into classrooms and community centers across Austin, reaching thousands. The Dumpster Project has also sparked a green transformation at Huston-Tillotson University, the Project’s home base, where students examine how social justice and environmental issues intersect. Finally, we believe strongly in the power of art to enrich, empower, and enlighten. We want to build a rich discourse between artists and sustainability actors. It is important for us to pay creators for their vital work. Your support of this campaign is critical to our plans.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you don't have any disposable income to pitch in right now. Thank you for taking the time to read our story, and you can still help!

Share our campaign! Spreading the word will help us reach our goal. You can use the Indiegogo share tools. Please keep up with our progress at dumpsterproject.org, and if you are inspired to create with us, apply to our Creative-in-Residence program.

Thank you for your interest and support!



(photo credits to Dumpster Project, Christine Giordano, and Sarah Natsumi Moore)

What is The Dumpster Project?The Dumpster Project’s goal is to turn a used 6’x6’ trash receptacle into a high-tech, sustainable, healthy, and beautiful microhome. Our project is collaborative, somewhat open-ended, and best of all, wildly engaging. The Dumpster Project has become many things: a re-imagining of home, a portable community learning tool, the means to a lively sustainability conversation, an innovative STEM education platform, and the anchor of a wider set of green campus initiatives at Huston-Tillotson University (HT), a historically black institution located in the heart of east Austin, Texas. Now we are inviting artists to reflect on the Dumpster-to-home transformation and create work that broadens our collective view of sustainability.We've learned that the challenge of transforming a trash dumpster into a tiny sustainable home inspires creative problem solving. We’ve seen second graders imagine bike-powered appliances, green builders envision heat-storing wax walls, and activists discuss “dumpster footprints” as an environmental impact measure. Now we invite even broader forms of thought-provoking experimentation with our Creative-in-Residence program. We're inviting artists and creators of all types to take on the dumpster challenge and re-envision some aspect of the project as we investigate the impacts of modern life.
Our First Creative-in-ResidenceWe are fundraising for our very first creative-in-residence, Bernadette Noll.  She’s an author, maker, and craft coordinator of Austin’s Mini Maker Faire. When Bernadette learned that we wanted to insulate the dumpster with natural materials, she immediately brainstormed ways to use reclaimed fabric. She decided on wool, which is a good insulator and improves air quality - a plus in our very small space. Bernadette designed and created a vibrant insulating wall panel from reclaimed wool that depicts the core Dumpster Project values of sustainability, home, and experimentation. It is beautiful and practical and represents everything the Dumpster Project is about – transforming a space into something good for you and for the environment.Joining Bernadette in forging the way for our new Creative-in-Residence program is Christine Giordano. She’s been documenting Bernadette’s project and generally being awesome. She is a producer and art director of television, film, and commercials.  She got her start interning on the award-winning documentary series FRONTLINE, and has recently served as Story Producer for RFD-TV's cowboy reality show All Around Performance Horse.  Christine has created online commercial content for brands such as Macy's, Verizon Wireless, and L'Oreal, and also directs digital shorts for the sketch comedy group GROOVY PARTY.  When she's not on set she is tending to her eleven chickens, twenty-thousand bees, and coordinating Austin's weekly ladies-only dance phenomenon, Dance Dance Party Party.Why a Dumpster?We get asked this a lot. If we want to build a sustainable home as a teaching and learning experiment, why don't we just use a shipping container or build a small eco-friendly home from scratch? There are two big reasons we use a tiny dumpster. The first has to do with exactly that, size. The dumpster is small! It has a 6’ by 6’ footprint on the ground and the interior square footage is about 36 square feet. This makes our task more challenging and pushes us to really innovate and rethink.The second reason is that dumpsters are symbols of, and receptacles for, waste. Many times, we throw trash into the dumpster and rarely consider where it goes after that, or what sort of impact we are having on the planet as a result. A big goal of the Dumpster Project is to raise awareness by making these invisible processes that affect us and the planet very tangible...say by transforming that very same magic waste-disappearing box into a home where every environmental repercussion is very apparent.
 
What this Campaign Will Pay For
This campaign will launch the Dumpster Project Creative-in-Residence Program. Proceeds will be split evenly among Bernadette, Christine, and the Dumpster Project non-profit organization. This will pay Bernadette and Christine for their time and work and cover the cost of materials used for Bernadette’s dumpster-inspired insulating wool wall hanging. Christine’s photos and videos will help us continue to use the dumpster as a platform to inspire and educate. The Dumpster Project share of the proceeds will cover operation costs, including staff and materials for the continuing dumpster transformation as well as costs of launching this new creative program.

Rewards!
There are awesome perks for donating, like an invitation to our super-cool dumpster party or our Dumpster Project craft night at Recycled Reads.  We’ve got Dumpster schwag like our “Yes we can!” t-shirts, tote bags, a brand new “Wish you were here” postcard, and a very few, super limited-edition dumpster cacti (made from recycled dumpsters). 


For our supporters in Austin or nearby, we also want to meet you and inspire your creativity. Bernadette is offering two craft nights for you and your friends. Using all reclaimed/recycled/re-sourced materials she will bring supplies for a totally cool utilitarian craft project. This ain’t no egg carton art. We'll hand stitch sweet felted wool wallets to protect your phone or hold your precious cards and cash. For humans of all skill levels, this project is good for beginners and expert stitchers.
If you just want to experience the Dumpster, you can book an evening for yourself in two ways. Upon successful completion of this campaign, we’ll want to celebrate, so we will be hosting a super-cool party for backers at our Partaaay level, or you can host your own Dumpster-themed date night or small event.


  Your Impact 
Your support of the Dumpster Project allows us to continue our mission to educate, inspire, and innovate as we transform a dumpster into a happy healthy home. We have brought our sustainability message into classrooms and community centers across Austin, reaching thousands. The Dumpster Project has also sparked a green transformation at Huston-Tillotson University, the Project’s home base, where students examine how social justice and environmental issues intersect. Finally, we believe strongly in the power of art to enrich, empower, and enlighten. We want to build a rich discourse between artists and sustainability actors. It is important for us to pay creators for their vital work. Your support of this campaign is critical to our plans.


    Other Ways You Can Help 



We understand if you don't have any disposable income to pitch in right now. Thank you for taking the time to read our story, and you can still help!
Share our campaign! Spreading the word will help us reach our goal. You can use the Indiegogo share tools. Please keep up with our progress at dumpsterproject.org, and if you are inspired to create with us, apply to our Creative-in-Residence program.
Thank you for your interest and support!

(photo credits to Dumpster Project, Christine Giordano, and Sarah Natsumi Moore)

story:
Phase 2:

This is the second phase of the campaign to raise funds to cover the cost of Gymnastics, summer camp, and now violin (starting late August). Through the first phase of "Aid Through Art" we were able to raise enough funds to cover some of Kylie's camp costs. I would like to thank everyone who helped us, we are extremely grateful for your support. I can’t wait to finish up the prints that I have been working on, and I am looking forward to new projects as we continue to raise the funds needed. We still have a ways to go to meet our initial goal but to make it a little easier I have decided to break it into phases with smaller goals. Again we thank you all for your support, we wouldn’t get by without our help. <3

Please see our previous campaign at: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/aid-through-art-for-kylie--2/x/10688718#/story

Below is our story:

My 7-year old daughter, Kylie, has struggled through more emotional turmoil than any child her age should ever have to experience and yet her spirit is unbroken. She has found her own outlets and talents and I have had the pleasure of watching her confidence grow she takes her own journey down the path self-discovery. In gymnastics, she has advanced two levels beyond her age group and she continues to put forth effort and hard work into learning new skills. She says “Mommy, my dream is to be in the Olympics someday.” Kylie is also very much enchanted by science and nature and she can’t get enough of the outdoors. Whether it’s fishing, swimming, camping or just walking through the woods, when she is surrounded by the beauty of nature it is plain to see that she is in her happy place.  Unfortunately, with the rising cost of summer camp and after-school care, I don’t think we can afford the cost of gymnastics or camp on my salary this summer.

Sometimes life may take you down a rough path, but the universe will always provide you with enough tools to survive. Even if those tools are hidden deep within. The resources are there if you look hard enough and are willing to go to any length. My burden of privilege is the eternal care for another life that I created. Sometimes my economic insecurities get the best of me and I am unable to provide the life I wish I could for my 7-year-old daughter. I was blessed with an artistic talent that has served no real purpose in my life aside from the ability to express myself on paper. I realized that my abilities may serve a greater purpose than for my own enjoyment. I hope to fund my daughter’s talent in gymnastics and her many other interests, with my talent in the arts and with your support.

story:
Tribal Breeze

We are each unique and everything we create is like a seed with our unique DNA that holds potential to bring forth all of who we are.  Tribal Breeze is a small expression of my biggest dream: of helping people start their projects and transform their community.  --Lena

 A vibrant team comes together to bring you my original three-way reversible tote filled with various artistic creations.  

Organic three-way reversible Tote 

Get all three looks in one bag!

Contributing Artists

It's the Journey:  We will journey with these artists over the next few weeks as their creations unfold and find out how their sundry works of art help develop their primary focus.  We will share more about what they are creating along the way. An event to  organize around, a deadline, and community: That's what Tribal Breeze is about.

  • Adam & Sharla Nickel - Adam is a filmmaker and Sharla a writer.  If you are doing anything even remotely courageous or worthwhile in the world, then they are your biggest fans, and she is our editor!
  • Amanda Rivera - Amanda is not just an artist, she is art. Whatever she touches comes alive, whether its stage, a vintage garb, or an empty canvas. 
  • Anonymous - Everything is art, step lightly, expect brilliance.  We expect as we journey that others will want to join.  We will add their items at random.
  • Emily Sulzberger- Emily is a student at Stella Adler and enjoys acting, singing, and storytelling.  She brightens a room the moment she enters.
  • Ernesto and Simona Escobar - Have managed restaurants and coffee shops and will soon have one of their own.  They have many talents, but share a love for found treasure and making something old new.
  • Kyla Giron - Kyla has been creating beautiful art since she could hold a paintbrush, and has excelled at many different mediums. She also enjoys running and personal training.  
  • Lena Giron - Lena is our catalyst who enjoys songwriting and filmmaking and lives to inspire others to live out their fullest potential through art and community projects.
  • Meg Giron - Meg is a math student at UCSC who loves dance and photography. You will savor the nostalgia she unearths in every photograph.  Her photographs are taken old school on 35mm film.
  • Nicolai Dorian - Nicolai is a seasoned actor who has an eye for chillness whether it's old cars, or photography which has him curating art shows at various venues in the LA area.
  • Tribe LA -  may let you think she is shy, but what boldness as she takes her drums and sings a melodious timbal improv.  Tribe LA is a place an artist can find community.

What We Need & What You Get

We need:  Most creative people simply need something to organize around and a deadline.  This is our biggest need.  

You get:  A great tote full of beautiful creations and the satisfaction that you helped teach a community to fish rather than simply giving them fish. And you will be first to see some of the works from these artists, many of whom are also teachers, writers, actors, dancers, musicians, filmmakers, inventors, and entrepreneurs. 

The Impact

Lena, Meg and Kyla are going to Ecuador this month with The Justice Group to serve the poor and free young people from trafficking.  Our goal is also to make a lasting impact.  We will start one of these projects in Ecuador and share that journey with you.  Every bag helps towards that goal as well as helping some local artists. 

Each of our contributing artists has a story, some have taken small steps towards long held dreams and others have felt a bit stuck.  Either way we are building community and momentum.

Risks & Challenges

The greatest risk we face is failing to see the importance of creativity and wasting our potential.  

So if an actor takes a beautiful photo and does nothing with it since there's so many 'real' photographers out there, it is like a seed that is never planted.  If, instead, that actor puts that seed in the ground by using the photo even in the smallest way, it has the potential to bring forth all of his strengths, problem solving, community involvement and his fullest potential as an actor. 

Every endeavor brings challenge, which in turn ignites creativity.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Be a part of the next project.  Get your seeds planted! Contact us for more info.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
SweeTooth Design Company is where foodies and designers meet. We are a group of researchers, foodies, and designers, who are passionate and exciting to bring knowledge to people who also love food. Began with our first food design, Genesis of Cookies, our team continues to strive and discover interesting story of delicious food, drinks, and desserts. Evolution of Ice Cream is what we wanted to introduce to you who also enjoy sweets and treats!


We don't take food for granted. Instead, we are curious about how and where our food came from. Although ice cream was believed to be invented in China 5000 years ago, many early recipes are deeply rooted and developed in Europe, especially Italy and France. Through our new design, Evolution of Ice Cream, you will learn and discover unexpected knowledge about your favorite frozen dessert!

Earl Grey and Maple Walnut Ice Cream, Photograph by City Foodsters



While designing, we pay close attention to specific serving dinnerware and utensils that were used during each historic period. We think it is best to portrait the entire presentation of the ice cream that corresponds to its time and place.

Vanilla and chocolate ice cream in a wafer basket, Photograph by City Foodsters

We also focus on how we present our knowledge to you in an easy-to-read format like how we did in Genesis of Cookies. Under each illustration, there is the name of each ice cream, place, and time of the invention.



The poster has two backgrounds:

LIGHT version is a beautifully photographed white marble background. It is as if you are looking at all the ice creams lining up on top of your kitchen counter top.

DARK version is a swirl of chocolate fountain. It adds a tasty flavor to the poster.

Each version is limited to 500 prints. Each print will be hand-numbered and signed. Poster is printed on 100% recycled 100lb. cover paper with matte finish. Dimension is 16x20 in inches.





Genesis of Cookies was the first food knowledge based poster our company designed. There are 30 cookies on the poster, and each is indicated with its documented origin of place and time. They are based on research that can be found HERE at our website.

What other media think about Genesis of Cookies?

"Now we have the low-down on how and when each cookie came about. SweeTooth Design has created a mouth-watering poster that illustrates the genesis of 30 of today’s most famous cookies." - Fast Company

"These posters made us come close to drooling over the illustrations of some classic but sweet treats. SweeTooth Design researched the history of cookies around the world and organized them together in this handy dandy infographic." - Paste Magazine

Evolution of Ice Cream (LIGHT) and Genesis of Cookie (DARK)

Genesis of Cookie (LIGHT)



SweeTooth Design Company has been using United States Postal Service (USPS) for the past 4 Kickstarter projects. For within US, we use First-Class Mail or Domestic Priority Mail. For all other destination outside of US, we use First-Class Mail International.

Since our first successfully funded Kickstarter project, our backers always receive their rewards on time or earlier than expected. For this project, expected delivery date is approximately December 2015 to January 2016.


Risks and challenges

Our team created 4 Kickstarter projects since March 2014. We are confident in our food designs and are very proud to bring sweet knowledge through our poster designs.

Since last year we designed, printed, and shipped over thousands of posters to people across the globe. We have learnt, adapted and improved our practices in many aspects. Due to our experience working with crowdfunding platform, our team had developed an efficient system to for our contributors.

story:
Why We Need Money.

1. We need to build the social media platform first, so the artists have a place to go.

2. We need to add the online market place, integrated with an auction house. The social platform and the online market place will be integrated, with a drag and click feature for easy posting of work straight from his/her profile to auction house or online market.

3. We will begin an ad campaign once we get the funding, this is to reach as many artists as possible. This is after all for the artists and their work.

4. We then will provide a place for collectors. This is where collectors can create a profile, describe what type of art they are interested in purchasing, or commissioning. They will then be given a list of artists profiles that match their interests along with any artwork they may have on the market place. The collector then can choose to display their purchase so the artist and the community can see it. This is to connect artist with collector like never before.

5. The performing arts will have to have a place too! They also will have a profile complete with video and music players. There will a job board where dancers, singers, etc. will be able to post their talent along with their contact info so any interested parties can get in touch with them. 

6. We will be including a live stream feature for performers. This is for their fans. They will be able to live stream their gigs straight to their profile, where their fans will be notified of the live stream so they can watch. This will also be available to all artists looking to live stream their process.

story:
Are you worried that Stephen Harper will be re-elected on October 19th? We're scared shitless! Well not quite, butt close. This may be seen as a smear campaign, and that's because it is. We don’t want to be sued for defecation of character, but it's high time we wipe the slate clean of Stephen Harper and elect a new leader to represent our true Canadian values.

We feel passionate about politics and toilet humour, two topics that go hand in hand, so we are offering 100% recycled toilet paper with the face of our Prime Ministurd printed on each and every square. You can wipe yourself clean, gift to your friends or better yet, replace the T.P. at your work and watch the shit storm!

(Feel free to download this picture and share it with your friends and use it as your Facebook profile picture)

If this resonates with you but you don't feel like ordering a roll, please share our video with your friends and educate yourself on how to vote strategically by checking out these websites: http://www.leadnow.ca/ and http://www.strategicvoting.ca/  

We need to reach as many voters across Canada. It's time to FLUSH HARPER OUT! 

Our campaign is non-profit, all money raised goes towards purchasing toilet paper and the costs are listed below. We welcome you to purchase a T.P. roll for us to distribute on your behalf or we will mail your order to you. Bonus if you live in Metro Vancouver, we will have an open house at ifyougiveashitvote headquarters where you could pick up your roll, so you can save on shipping costs. 

What We Need & What You Get

We have two basic asks if you want to help us roll out the campaign:

1. We need you to share our video with your friends and family, to inspire as many Canadians to vote strategically.

2. We would love it if you purchase some toilet paper, and more importantly, wiped your bum with it. Now we know these T.P. rolls are not cheap, and we searched for a local printer to no avail. A supplier from Illinois offered us the best price and fastest shipping. All prices below are per roll:

·  Custom Printed Toilet Paper: $7.25 (includes Sales Tax) Don't believe us? Check out our supplier, based on 500 minimum roll order. http://www.asi71068.com/
·  American Shipping UPS: $1.20
·  Import Duty: $1.00
·  CDN Taxes (GST + PST): $0.90
·  Shipping is same price for 1 to 3 rolls and varies only slightly from BC to Quebec and beyond: $10.50

We offer Five Perks:

·  Perk #1: If you make a donation to our campaign by purchasing a roll or more, we will distribute your roll in a swing riding where we desperately need people to vote strategically. Total for 1 ROLL with NO shipping $11.00. *If you live in Metro Vancouver and want to pick up your roll at ifyougiveashitvote headquarters and save $, purchase this perk.* 

·  Perk #2: If you want your own roll we will ship a roll directly to your house. Total for 1 ROLL with shipping: $22.00.

·  Perk #3: If you want two rolls shipped directly to your house. Total for 2 ROLLS with shipping: $33.00 (that's only $16.50 per roll!)

·  Perk #4: If you want three rolls shipped directly to your house. Total for 3 ROLLS with shipping: $43.00 (that's only $14.33 per roll!)

·  Perk #5: If you want four rolls shipped directly to your house. Total for 4 ROLLS with shipping: $54.00 (that's only $12.98 per roll!)

Expensive for a single roll of toilet paper? Definitely. But the joy of wiping your ass with Harper's face? PRICELESS.

The Impact

To the conservative advantage, Canada’s political landscape has split the progressive vote three ways. This has lead to the Harper Government winning the last election with 39% of the popular vote, but getting 100% of the power. We are at a time when progressive Canadians need to vote together and vote strategically. We want the next government to bring in some form of proportional representation, so no Canadian’s vote is wasted. We hope to make people laugh, discuss politics, pull up their pants and get out there and VOTE!

Risks & Challenges

We recognize time is short, but we have assurances from the printer that they can rush the job. We are confident we can execute receiving the American shipment and process the Canadian shipment and have the T.P. rolls in people’s hands 5 days prior to the election. Sufficient time for even the most bunged up supporters.
story_txt:
Are you worried that Stephen Harper will be re-elected on October 19th? We're scared shitless! Well not quite, butt close. This may be seen as a smear campaign, and that's because it is. We don’t want to be sued for defecation of character, but it's high time we wipe the slate clean of Stephen Harper and elect a new leader to represent our true Canadian values.
We feel passionate about politics and toilet humour, two topics that go hand in hand, so we are offering 100% recycled toilet paper with the face of our Prime Ministurd printed on each and every square. You can wipe yourself clean, gift to your friends or better yet, replace the T.P. at your work and watch the shit storm! (Feel free to download this picture and share it with your friends and use it as your Facebook profile picture)
If this resonates with you but you don't feel like ordering a roll, please share our video with your friends and educate yourself on how to vote strategically by checking out these websites: http://www.leadnow.ca/ and http://www.strategicvoting.ca/  We need to reach as many voters across Canada. It's time to FLUSH HARPER OUT! 
Our campaign is non-profit, all money raised goes towards purchasing toilet paper and the costs are listed below. We welcome you to purchase a T.P. roll for us to distribute on your behalf or we will mail your order to you. Bonus if you live in Metro Vancouver, we will have an open house at ifyougiveashitvote headquarters where you could pick up your roll, so you can save on shipping costs. 
What We Need & What You Get
We have two basic asks if you want to help us roll out the campaign:
1. We need you to share our video with your friends and family, to inspire as many Canadians to vote strategically.
2. We would love it if you purchase some toilet paper, and more importantly, wiped your bum with it. Now we know these T.P. rolls are not cheap, and we searched for a local printer to no avail. A supplier from Illinois offered us the best price and fastest shipping. All prices below are per roll:

story:
Support Manual Students and the Arts!

Manual High School, located in the heart of one of Denver's most historic neighborhoods, has long been a beacon for the performing arts. As the non-profit arm that supports the school, Friends of Manual is fundraising to update the sound and light systems in Manual's historic 1,200-seat auditorium to support student performances and to enhance all programming conducted in the facility. 

We are also rededicating the auditorium in honor of Dr. Joyce Marie Davis, who served as Manual's choir teacher for more than 20 years and directed the award-winning Bolt Vibration. This project cements her legacy and ensures future students will continue to appreciate her contributions to MHS and its surrounding community. 

The much-needed sound and lighting systems upgrades will fully showcase the talents of Manual students and their dedication to the musical and performing arts. Just this past month, the GRAMMY Foundation awarded MHS its Signature Schools Community Award for outstanding efforts in musical education. Additionally, the upgrades will enhance other school activities, such as assemblies and graduation ceremonies, and support the school's ability to host community events. 

All upgrades will be on display at the annual Winter Showcase on Friday, December 11th, at 7pm at Manual High School. The showcase will feature student performances and the Holiday Celebration Choir of community members and former Bolt Vibration members. The show will be preceded by a reception and rededication ceremony honoring Dr. Davis. 

The Winter Showcase is a wonderful way to get your family into the holiday spirit while supporting Manual High School.  

What We Need & What You Get

Friends of Manual's fundraising campaign will cover the cost of sound, lighting, and other equipment upgrades to Manual High School's auditorium. The first phase of the campaign offers each donor a commemorative engraved 1" x 4" plaque to be placed on an auditorium seat. The plaques can be used to honor a Manual graduate, to recognize a special teacher or administrator, or to demonstrate community support - donors can customize within the allotted space from 1-3 lines, depending on donation level. We prefer payment via credit/debit card through this platform but you may also bring cash or a check (made out to Friends of Manual) to Carol Grant in the main office of the school. All donations are fully tax-deductible. 
FRIENDS OF MANUAL WILL CONTACT EACH DONOR SEPARATELY FOR PLAQUE ENGRAVING ORDERS AFTER MAKING THE DONATION. PLEASE SEE THE GALLERY TAB AT TOP OF THE PAGE TO VIEW A SAMPLE PLAQUE (1" X 4"). 
  • One short engraved line for a $50 donation (ex: John Smith)
  • Two short engraved lines for a $100 donation (ex: John Smith; Class of '78)
  • Three short engraved lines for a $150 donation (ex: In memory of; Terry Smith; Go Bolts!)

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can support this initiative in important ways:

  • Share the campaign link on Facebook, other social media, and via email.
  • Tell your friends about this important project and 
  • Attend the Winter Showcase on Friday, December 11th at 7pm at Manual High School. Tickets will be sold the night of the show at the door ($8 adults, $4 students, free for pre-school children)

Thank you for supporting Manual High School and the arts!

story: I'm a Moroccan artist living and working in Chicago. I've been creating mandalas for almost 7 years now but I have been an artist my whole life. I feel very good when I make these patterns and through research I've found out there is immense psychological benefits in observing and creating these patterns. I decided after many requests from my fans on social media that I'd create a coloring book. So far I have 20 pages completed and it's ready for publication. I'm seeking self publication and need help raising funds to help produce and distribute these coloring books around the world. Thank you!
