Who we are?

We are final year TV production students 
We want people to know more about the Jordan culture and traditions
Our aim is to observe the life of Bedouins who live with no access to the technology in the middle of the desert 


What We Need & What You Get

We need 1,500 GBP to cover the expenses for our final year project (this includes flight tickets, accommodation, transportation, filming permissions)
We want to put all our creative input and time and to make a documentary that will be interesting for you! We want to educate our audience, inspire them about Jordan culture and also explore the challenged Bedouins face as a result of the tourism.


Other Ways You Can Help
It would be really helpful if you can share this campaign with your connections, friends and family.  We want to thank you for your time and cooperation!

story:
Who Am I?

I am a freelance illustrator from Toronto, Ontario, now based in Chicoutimi, Québec. I studied illustration at OCADU in Toronto, and graduated in 2013 with a Bachelor of Design. During my studies, I had a difficult time figuring out what inspired me. Overtime, I came to realize that nature and children's art were two of the most influential sources of inspiration for myself.

Ever since my graduation almost 3 years ago, I have come to discover that being an illustrator is a very precarious job, but that hasn't stopped me from pursuing my passion, or from looking for ways that I can develop my illustrations into marketable products that people will enjoy.

Now that I live in Chicoutimi, I have had the chance to be exposed to a different environment from that of Toronto. Chicoutimi is much closer to nature, surrounded by parks, and other beautiful villages and cities are only a few hours away. Being here has inspired me to create art inspired by the landscapes and animals.

So, what are Forest Friends pins?

Forest friends pins is a self-initiated project where I will design enamel pins featuring some animals that I have seen in Québec. For me, turning my illustrations into enamel pins is a viable way to turn my work into something marketable. I have seen many others design enamel pins, and it is clear why people like enamel pins so much- they are fun, cute, and each one is unique.

So far I have a few designs featuring birds like the chickadee, goldfinch and dark-eyed junco; I also have a design for a fox. If this campaign is successful, I will look into making other variations. The designs are below:

 

Why did I start this campaign?

I started this campaign to embark on a new project that I have wanted to do for years, but never had the time or funding to do so. That is where you will come in. All contributions will go towards the production of the enamel pins, packaging design and printing, and costs for advertising. I will be selling these pins via etsy, and marketing them through social media, so paying for advertisements will be necessary. Besides selling the pins online, my goal is to have them sold in small boutiques.

How can you help?

Any monetary contribution, small or big, will be greatly appreciated. But I understand not everyone will have the means to do so, in which case you can also contribute by sharing my campaign via Facebook, Instagram, Tumblr, etc....the success of this campaign will rely greatly on this.

I will be sharing the page via:

Instagram @carolinew_illustration

Facebook: www.facebook.com/carolinewillustration

Tumblr: www.carolinewillustration.tumblr.com

 

What's in it for you?

With your contributions, you can receive some things created by me:

When you make a donation, if you wish to receive any of the perks below, you must select it from the list on the side, otherwise you will just make a donation without receiving a gift in return. These perks are my way of saying thank you for your contribution!

$5- cupcake wallpaper

A cute wallpaper for your computer.

$12- Walrus birthday card

An adorable birthday card featuring a happy walrus. Keep it for yourself, or give it to a loved one!

 

$20 Fox, Dark-eyed Junco, Goldfinch or Chickadee pin

You choose a pin based on the designs below.


 

$30- Custom mini pet portrait

I will make a custom portrait of your pet, painted on a 2.5 x 2.5" wooden brooch.

$50- Facebook portrait of you (and your pet)

I will draw a black and white portrait of yourself and your pet for a Facebook profile picture. It will be delivered in jpeg format to you via email.

$80- All 4 pins (Fox, Chickadee, Dark-Eyed-Junco, and Goldfinch)

You will receive all 4 of the pins, based on the designs above.

$100- Puppy Love painting

An original painting, unframed, 9" x 12".

 

$100- Top Dog painting

An original painting, unframed, 9" x 12".

 

$200- Custom pet portrait

I will make a custom portrait of your pet, painted on a 8" x 10" canvas.

 

Thank you so much for your help! :)

Any monetary contribution, small or big, will be greatly appreciated. But I understand not everyone will have the means to do so, in which case you can also contribute by sharing my campaign via Facebook, Instagram, Tumblr, etc....the success of this campaign will rely greatly on this.
I will be sharing the page via:
Instagram @carolinew_illustration
Facebook: www.facebook.com/carolinewillustration
Tumblr: www.carolinewillustration.tumblr.com
 

What's in it for you?

With your contributions, you can receive some things created by me:
When you make a donation, if you wish to receive any of the perks below, you must select it from the list on the side, otherwise you will just make a donation without receiving a gift in return. These perks are my way of saying thank you for your contribution!
$5- cupcake wallpaper
A cute wallpaper for your computer. 
$12- Walrus birthday card
An adorable birthday card featuring a happy walrus. Keep it for yourself, or give it to a loved one!

 
$20 Fox, Dark-eyed Junco, Goldfinch or Chickadee pin
You choose a pin based on the designs below.

 
$30- Custom mini pet portrait
I will make a custom portrait of your pet, painted on a 2.5 x 2.5" wooden brooch.

$50- Facebook portrait of you (and your pet)
I will draw a black and white portrait of yourself and your pet for a Facebook profile picture. It will be delivered in jpeg format to you via email.
$80- All 4 pins (Fox, Chickadee, Dark-Eyed-Junco, and Goldfinch)
You will receive all 4 of the pins, based on the designs above.
$100- Puppy Love painting
An original painting, unframed, 9" x 12".

 
$100- Top Dog painting
An original painting, unframed, 9" x 12".

 
$200- Custom pet portrait
I will make a custom portrait of your pet, painted on a 8" x 10" canvas.

 
Thank you so much for your help! :)

story:
The Nitty Gritty 

• Diane Da Costa, a celebrity stylist and curly hair expert, has been glamorizing women for the past 30 years. She is the author of the book Textured Tresses and the founder of the Harlem CurlyTexturedBAR (Harlem CtBAR), which will open in 2018. 

• Previously Diane opened the first multi-textured Aveda concept salon in Manhattan and she currently owns her own salon, SimpleeBEAUTIFUL CurlyTexturedBAR in Westchester, New York.

• As a curly, textured hair expert, Diane is all about beautifying, educating and styling curly, textured hair. Over the years, Diane has created a community where women with wavy, curly and coily hair can embrace their natural beauty, exchange meaningful conversations and purchase botanical hair products. 

• The Harlem CtBAR will offer a beauty lounge for consultations, coloring, cuts, new hair technology, hair extensions, treatments, express blow-outs and textured styling.

• In a fast-paced society, having access to a one-stop-shop that also sells high-end botanical hair products is an important option for women to experience. The Harlem CtBAR will provide curly girls with a place to chill, commune and get pampered, while purchasing beauty products, hair accessories and tools designed for women with multi-textured hair. 

• The Harlem CtBAR will bring much needed beauty services, specifically for natural and curly women to Harlem!

• The salon will also educate young, talented people from the community who want to acquire a natural hair specialist & advanced training in cutting and styling curly, textured hair.

 

What We Need & What You Get

▪ A total of $5,000 is needed to fund this campaign. Contributions will be used to provide training for staff so that they can service all of our guests in the most efficient way, plus training specifically for blow-outs, textured styling, color and cutting techniques.

• Our unique perks include makeover packages executed by Diane Da Costa, a limited-edition, DYAKIM Textured Turban towel (the best quickdry microfiber hair towel on the market), and VIP entrance to the exclusive fundraising party for the CurlyTexturedBAR!

• All funds will be used to train coordinators, administrative staff and stylists.

• In addition, a portion of the proceeds raised from this crowd funding campaign will be donated to Diane’s favorite charity, The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation!

 

The Impact

While there are several blow-dry bars throughout Manhattan, the Harlem CtBAR will be the first and only salon offering blow-outs, ceramic and textured styling in Harlem specifically for wavy, curly and coily hair textures. Harlem women will now be able to get the best luxury and express services that are offered to the rest of New York in a fun and sexy environment. Guests will also be able to relax with and have a cocktail in hand! Those who require “express service” will be serviced within 90 minutes. Your contribution will provide invaluable training to staff and employees who are predominately from our community.

 

Risks & Challenges

The Harlem CtBAR is scheduled to open this summer 2018, but construction can be unpredictable. All rewards will be honored when the salon opens.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Diane thanks you all for your contributions! Even if you can’t contribute monetarily you can still help her achieve her goal. Just get the word out and share this campaign with your friends! You can use IndieGoGo’s social media tools to make it super easy.

story:
Click link to donate to Round 2: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/join-me-in-t...

ShineOnGifts shops was officially founded in January 2017 though it has been brewing on the back burner for several years. I cannot let go of this dream to start the first of a chain of gift shops which will feature local quality hand made gifts made by individuals.

I have been in commission sales for the past 16 years and prior to that, I started a successful service business which grew to 3 shifts and multiple contractual clients. I operated this business, Shine On Janitorial Svc.  for 7 years.  Though it provided exceptional service to businesses and residential clients,  paid the bills and provided income to others, it was not my main passion.  

I envision Shine On Gifts being an asset in local communities as I plan on going out in local under served neighborhoods and setting up volunteer children workshops during after school hours 3:00-6:00 when the children are out of school but the parents are not home from work. We can teach the kids jewelry, ornament,  stuffed animals and pillow making and various crafts that they can sell in the "Kids Corner" of our shops. This will provide them with an allowance that they may not otherwise be able to earn.

Let's face it, online sellers like Amazon and Etsy are easy to get lost in.  They lack the personal touch, the hands on face to face contact that a creative shop experience provides. Not the usual stuffy corporate scripted sales pitch but a very user friendly and classy shopping experience.  Did I mention supporting local musicians as well? Yes, I'll hire guitar, flute, and piano players to provide background music for the shoppers to enjoy during special events and busy holiday shopping hours!

After the first year, I envision the shop being self sufficient and able to grow in other communities. After all, it is a shop for everyone! Here's where the initial funding donations will go:

$25,000  One year lease approx. 1500 sq ft retail space in an Atlanta Strip Mall

  15,000    6 months mixed media marketing & advertising

    4,000    Insurance, permits, licensing and signs for the shop

     3,000    Initial inventory for the shop

      3,000   Shop shelving, tables & supplies

$50,000 Total start up costs

 What you get is a chance to support starting a business that ultimately will come full circle back to you!  If you or someone you know make things, I'd love to sell those things! If you like supporting your local community, this is a great idea for that!  Shine On Gifts is about reaching out to our individual creative roots and developing passion for other's unique creations. Another concrete platform to sell what our own hands produced and shop for special goods created within our communities!

This is the part where I am to describe where the funds will go if I do not reach my goal. This seems like a negative thought to me. I will use the funds to build ShineOnGifts until my goal is met. 

Your contribution will be valued whether it's $3.00 or $10,000.  Every dollar will count in getting the door open.  I know you all have more than money to contribute once the doors are open, the lights are on and we are setting up the shop. I want to support your ideas, too! We will be in partnership to have fun in our communities and Shine On Together!

The Risks and Challenges

I have been thinking about the right time and method to start this business.  The risk and challenge is generating enough interest in the local community to keep the business developing and growing. I want to dedicate most of my time doing this as I believe it can be done.  I need to get the idea out where others can see it, experience and enjoy it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can or cannot contribute, there is another BIG way you can show support:

Please help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. You can use the Indiegogo share tools.

And that's all there is to it!

story:
Summary

  • Terrault Gallery and Platform Gallery, two artist-run, Baltimore galleries, each with two years of successful programming, are returning to the invitational free alternative art fair, Satellite Art Show for Art | Basel Miami Beach, to be held December 1-4, 2016.
  • We are fundraising together and sharing all profits in the spirit of collaboration and community!
  • We will expose, promote, and sell the work of Baltimore-area artists and performers to curators, critics, and collectors nationally and globally, underscoring the vibrancy of Baltimore’s robust artist scene.
  • This means putting Baltimore artists, and artist-run spaces on the map as a key player in the international art scene! We expect to have over 90,000+ people through our exhibition doors!
  • This helps us keep our Baltimore artists living and working here, instead of leaving for other cities.
  • We need your help to be able to make this happen! We need to raise $16,000 just to break even for all of the expenses in order to bring a taste of the artist-run Baltimore flavor to Miami!
  • Artists we are showcasing are but not limited to: Katie Duffy, Lesser Gonzalez Alvarez, Christopher McCarthy, Cheyenne Woodward, Alex Ebstein, Amanda Martinez, and Esther Ruiz.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are fundraising in a multitude of ways to reach our $16,000 goal to be able to break even with all of our costs associated with participating in the fair.
  • All funds go to covering participation fees ($10,000), packing and shipping (~$2,000), installation costs(~$1,000), travel and lodging(~$2,000), and per diem expenses (~$1,000).
  • By contributing you know that you will have helped us make our dreams come true and give us the opportunity to showcase on a scale like never before! Which gives us the opportunity to increase our sustainability and keep thriving and curating shows and events back in Baltimore and beyond.
  • For donating $30 you will get a locally made surprise ZINE from Terrault's inventory!
  • For donating $100 you will get a print from one of the pieces we show in our exhibitions. A print from either Lesser Gonzalez Alvarez, or Esther Ruiz. 
  • If the entire goal is not met, every penny is still extremely helpful to help us recuperate from our expenses.
  • We are fundraising in a number of ways to met out $16K goal. We have applied for and received some grants and donations (have already raised $7,000), and are also holding the fundraiser show on November 12th at The Crown (https://www.facebook.com/events/303590406690116/), in addition to crowd funding.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to the campaign, but want to help you can:

  • Come to our fundraiser show at The Crown on Saturday, November 12th -
    $10 Show featuring Elon, Kotic Couture, Sun Club, Al Rogers, Jr., Trillnatured, Ducky Dynamo, Ellen Degenerate, Lexie Mountain, and Hella Freckles. Facebook event listed below.
    (https://www.facebook.com/events/303590406690116/)
  • Tell your friends to come to the fundraiser show!
  • Share this campaign on your social media and help us spread the word!

About SATELLITE ART FAIR

SATELLITE , now in it’s second year, is an alternative art fair that presents new and conceptually rigorous projects that span the gamut of art, music, performance, installation, new media and tech. Our 2015 show was highly attended by informed collectors and museum curators, received rave reviews from major art publications and had solid sales throughout the week.

SATELLITE 2.0 will be held at the Parisian Hotel, NEXT DOOR to Aqua Art Fair and steps from Art Basel and Untitled. The move to South Beach places SATELLITE in the heart of the action, providing us with unparalleled access to collectors and arts patrons alike. SATELLITE 2.0 will once again emphasize concept-driven rooms, rather than the typical salon style hang of the standard fairs.

 

Terrault and Platform would like to thank and acknowledge the William G. Baker, Jr. Memorial Fund, creator of the Baker Artist Portfolios, www.BakerArtist.org, and Jane Brown for their generous support of our project.

story:
I, Mbali Dhlamini (b. Johannesburg, South Africa, 1990; MA University of the Witwatersrand, 2015) am a multidisciplinary artist and coordinator. I perform visual, tactile and discursive investigations into current indigenous cultural practices. With a view towards decolonized practices in contemporary culture, my work is in constant conversation with my past and present visual landscapes. Working to maintain a state of unlearning and relearning, my process recognizes language as a medium of understanding and as a repository of knowledge.

I, have been selected as a fellow for the Raw Academie Session 2 untitled Angazi, but I'm sure. RAW Académie is a tuition-free residential experiential study programme for artistic and curatorial thought and practice inquiry of eight weeks in Dakar. It is dedicated to a lively reflection on artistic research, curatorial practice and critical writing. The academy is held during two distinct sessions per year; October–December and April–June. Each session is directed by a Lead Faculty who has displayed an off-the-beaten-track practice in regard to artistic, curatorial and critical imagination. Session 2 will be led by Chimurenga, the Cape Town based pan-African platform for writing, art and politics. It will take place from 3rd April to 26th May 2017.

RAW Academy appeals to me as a young graduate as it offers platforms for critical thinking and engagement as I am in pursuit of opportunities that allow for artistic research, collaboration and public interaction. I am currently working on a new research project as well as creative work, and trust RAW Academy will provide me with a space and platform to create, experiment and expand my research in different contexts.

The programme is self funded, and thus would like to request funding assistance to make the project a success. The funds raised will help cover:

*Return ticket From Johannesburg to Dakar = 681,83 dollars

Accommodation (8 weeks) = 1515,17 dollars

 * 8 weeks Living plus commuting expenses = 1136,38 dollars

 Materials and printing cost = 378,79 dollars

Total cost = 3712.17 dollars

Along side this campaign I will also host a fundraising sale of my own work. 

The programme encourages cultural exchanges and implementation of artistic research making room for Pan African interchanges and collaborations. There is limited funding and opportunities that encourage movement and collaboration within the continent. That poses a challenge to pan african collaborations and exchanges especially for young black female artist.

RAW Académie exposes participating fellows and Lead Faculty to the contemporary critical and dynamic artistic environment of Dakar as well as its history, while providing them with a free space for exploration, investigation, research and production of their own ideas. The programme is designed to promote intense exchange and continuous dialogue organized around public and closed sessions that include seminars, presentations, research and practice time, and visits of cultural institutions. Exhibitions and publications will be planned within this context for production and execution at a later stage. Each academy session is built around a relevant conceptual framework elaborated by the Lead Faculty with contributions of invited fellow professionals. The conceptual framework is a compelling basis for the analysis and production of the fellows’ as well as the faculty’s work and areas of inquiry. The Lead faculty has the absolute freedom for the conception of her/his project for the session. You can read more about it here http://www.rawmaterialcompany.org/_about- RAW-academy.

Should you not be able to assist financially please share the campaign across your network. You can also visit me blog on http://mbalidhlamini.tumblr.com and website http://cargocollective.com/mbalidhlamini  to see what I get up to in Dakar. You can also to contact me via email on mbalidhlamini@yahoo.co.uk should you want to know more about the project.

Kelebogile,

Thank you.

story:
MADE IN THE KINGDOM OF BELGIUM


 

Designed to enhance the natural beauty of the jellyfish.

Sit back and rejoice in the subtle, fluid movements of your jellyfish in a habitat specially designed for them. Let the shadows cast on the walls and ceiling hypnotize you. Scrutinize their alien anatomy through the curved dome, which acts as a magnifying glass. Perfectly rounded and with fluid lines which echo the delicate shape of the creatures within, the Darwin Tank gives the impression there is but a single membrane between the water and the air. A drop of the ocean, right in your home…

 

After months of research, the first prototype!

Jellyfish are surprisingly poor swimmers, and are carried along by currents, no matter how weak. This is why we devised a system allowing the pump to aspirate the water without harming the jellyfish. After months of extensive research, several prototypes and the valuable advice about fluid dynamics from Professor Jeroen van Beeck from the von Karman Institut, we perfected our StreamMaker. Rigged with LEDs, our 375mm high prototype allows us to admire the evolution of 3 to 4 adult Aurelia aurita jellyfish.

 

Who are we ?

Florence Samain and Dave Monfort. We are the founders of The Darwin Sect, which, since its conception in 2014, showcases a vast array of insects, beautifully staged in Napoleonic era globes. We are passionate about letting people discover the natural beauty occurring in the world around us. To do this we continuously search for new inspiration which can reawaken childlike wonder, which we continuously find in the limitless ingenuity of nature.

press release about the Darwin Tank

 

How does the Darwin Tank work?

The shape of our aquarium implies that the opening is underneath, which is made possible by an adjustable Inox clasp with quick fittings. This clasp exerts an equal pressure on bevelled sides and contours of the globe and the bottom, called the flange. The prefect seal of the aquarium is guaranteed by the O-ring seal which is nestled in the flange of the globe. 

 To open the tank, it has to be turned upside down. Due to its substantial weight when filled, you will need to empty the aquarium partially to facilitate and complete any and all manipulations. Once the aquarium has been partially emptied, paying close attention that the jellyfish are still comfortable, the aquarium can be easily handled and opened.



Counterparts

 

  • Postcards = 10$

             4 postcards  - jellyfish by Ernst Haeckel - 1905

  • Tote Bag = 25 $
         cotton tote bag / sac en coton - Darwin Sect logo
         + Postcards

     
  • 4 Jellyfish = 100 $

              4 Aurelia aurita - Medium size
              + Postcards + Tote Bag

  • The Darwin Tank Full Kit - Earlybird = 1640 $

    !! GET 20% OFF  !!  only 8 available

              1 x Darwin Tank 
              1 x base / socle
              1 x Filter / Filtre
              1 x LED system
            (package weight +-  32 kg)
             + Postcards + Tote Bag

  • The Darwin Tank Full Kit  = 1970 $

              1 x Darwin Tank 
              1 x base / socle
              1 x Filter / Filtre
              1 x LED system
           (package weight +-  32 kg)
             + Postcards + Tote Bag

 

 

A bit of engineering
 

1. The globe in Boro

The globe has to resist the pressure of the water within, therefore we have chosen one of the most resistant transparent materials : Boro 3.3, specially created for laboratory use. Our globes are fabricated in Belgium by Pierreglas. Experts in their field since decades, this exemplary partner has supported us since the conception of our product.


2. The StreamMaker

We manufacture this element out of a super clear acrylic. This production, which will be done by Clem in Kortrijk, Belgium requires the thermoforming of the acrylic elements. This acrylic piece is crystal clear and can be replace if needed.


3. The external filter

The Darwin Tank was developed to be used with an external filter. In the kit on offer, we have chosen a model that allows the speed of the pump to be regulated manually (the model depend on your country). The filter is connected to the pump by 12/16mm (int/ext) hoses.

4. The quick fittings 

The Darwin Tank is attached to the filter by two quick fittings attached to the bottom of the globe. These fittings are self-locking, no liquid can escape when released. Releasing the quick fittings happens by the simple press of a button.

 


5. The base

The Darwin Tank rests on a base which hides the hoses which connect the external filter. The base is manufactured in MDF and is 110cm high, and 32cm wide. A door allows easy access to the external filter system, the lighting system, and the filling pump. The base weighs 20 kilos.

6. The lighting system 

We have opted for RGB LEDs, which can be individually controlled and which give a beautiful light effect They can diffuse 3 spectrums: red, green and blue. By carefully mixing the colors and by playing with their intensity it is possible to create a warm white light (3000K) or a colder white (6000K).

 

Packing

The delivery fees include a special polystyrene box made for a safe transport. This box will also be use as a support for your globe during cleaning. 
 

 

Several species for your Darwin Tank…

Aurelia aurita

The moon jelly as she is commonly known, measures between 2 and 10 cm, and thrives in a habitat between 14 and 26°C with a salinity between 1024 and 1028. This species is the most common and is found globally. Easy to maintain in an aquarium.

Mastigias papua

The spotted jelly, lagoon jelly, golden medusa, or Papuan jellyfish measures between 2 and 8cm, and thrives in a habitat at 18 to 24°C with a salinity between 1024 and 1028. Requires full spectrum lighting.

Cotylorhiza tuberculata

Commonly known as a Mediterranean jelly or fried egg jellyfish, this species measures between 2 and 5cm, and thrives in a habitat between 20 and 27°C with a salinity of 1024 and 1028. Requires full spectrum lighting.

Rhopilema esculentum

Also called the flame jellyfish, measuring between 3 and 8cm, she thrives in a habitat between 20 and 27°C with a salinity of 1024 to 1028. Requires full spectrum lighting.

Phyllorhiza panctata

A spotted Austrailian species, measuring between 4 to 8 cm, its ideal habitat is water between 24 and 28°C with a salinity of 1024 to 1028. Requires full spectrum lighting.

Catostylus mosaicas

Also called blue blubbers jellyfish, measuring between 3 and 8 cm, this jellyfish thrives in water between 24 and 28°C with a salinity of 1024 to 1028.

Acromitus flagellatus

A spotted Austrailian species of jellyfish, measuring between 4 to 8 cm, its ideal habitat is water between 24 and 28°C with a salinity of 1024 to 1028. Requires full spectrum lighting.

 

Jellyfish breeders list

exoticaquaculture.com - HONG KONG
jellyfishconcept.fr - FRANCE
acuariodemedusas.com - SPAIN
ukjellyfish.co.uk - UK
jellyfishwarehouse.com - USA
jellyfishworld.com - CANADA
more coming soon ...

story:
E Komo Mai

The Hawaiian translation for Kino Pālua is dual natured.  Pele’, the Hawaiian volcano Goddess’ Element is Fire. Her Sea-Goddess sister, Namka or Nā-maka-o-Kahaʻi, the eyes of Kahaʻi is Water. They represented the two seemingly eternal enemies, Fire and Water. As a result of jealous rage, Pele’ and her sister became the most bitter enemies, fighting against each other with stormy floods and violent volcanic destruction. My intention in creating this project is  a way to heal our own inner duality, showing the higher relationship between Fire and Water and directing this healing into the Universe for all.   This is a way to express your pain in a more compassionate way. Soften your heart and relationship to help bring about your healing.

Kino Pālua is the second large scale project by Bay Area artist, Kahai Sumida-Tate. Bringing Pa'hao'aho - The Volcano to the playa in 2014, the journey of transformation continues within Kino Pālua.  

Two 16' x 24' temporary, wooden structures, intended to remind you to embrace the idea immediacy, Kino Pālua will welcome you to become at one and interact with the 'ahi' or 'wai' sides of the sculpture. Feel the heat and hear the roar of the 6 propane poofers as you let it all go inside ahi, and be soothed by the calming and embracing experience awaiting  you inside wai. A truly dual-natured experience. 

We need your support!

We're a small crew and need your help to bring Kino Pālua to life at Burning Man this summer! By supporting our project, you will be part of a community of people who come together to help realize large scale art. Funds will cover materials, transportation, build location rental among all the other things including pyrotechnics! We will have an opening ceremony with some hula dancing, fire spinning, art cars and a beautiful fireworks show.

Some Sweet Perks

In return, we have a bunch of great perks for you to purchase including a few super-cool 'can only get from our crew' items made especially for you, by us. 

Have you seen Al's Plasma Popper? Check it out here!

Beautiful handmade Chakra Bracelets to keep you balanced

OMG! Now is your chance to get your very own Blastaround Animal Scooter! For kids both young and young at heart! Created by our lighting guru, Andrew, this is the coolest whip in town. You can choose either a Tiger or a Lion for your custom Blastaround electric animal scooter. MEOW! * Decommissioned means it was a prototype animal, these aren't ever for sale - this is the only chance to get one!

One-of-a-kind Turquoise Necklace from Tara Lyn Evans Designs 

See more beautiful pieces in her Etsy Store.

The Crew

We are a group of artists who also have full time jobs (it ain't easy livin' in the Bay Area!). Our only risk is of ourselves working too damn much this summer - but it will be worth it! We can't wait to get started on construction. We are savvy and experienced builders AND burners, the phoenix will rise. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word and make some noise about our project.  We also are looking for in-kind donations of construction materials such as lumber, pallets, nails, lighting and of course help with the building process too. And also food! we love eating if you want to visit us on a build day! 

 

Mahalo for continuing this journey with us!

Creation, Destruction and Transformation on your Fire journey. Intention, Devotion and Love on your Water journey.

story:
Short Summary

Consider the Lilies is the first Off-Broadway production by House Red Theatre Company. the New York stage giant Austin Pendleton chose to be involved after a table-reading in an apartment on the Upper West Side in the spring of 2013. From there the team had a formal play reading at the Mint Theatre in the fall of 2013. For the next three years the team searched for funding to bring this dream to life. This is going to be a first Off-Broadway production for many involved, so the excitement is high.

We are seeking funds to publicize the production and market to audiences so they will see this event. We plan to advertise in all the major New York publications to get reviews, which could further interest in the production.

  • With the assistance from you good people on IndieGogo we will be able to reach out to the major publications for advertising. Without the advertising and reviews, this production could sink into oblivion without anyone knowing about us, knowing about the original play, Austin's efforts on stage, the supporting casts' efforts, the hard work from designers and builders. The list is long. So many people will be working to put this on, but without your support we could have empty houses. Competition is thick in New York.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We are seeking $12,500 to get the word out. We have a great publicist ready to roll, but we need your support so she can do her job. She's extremely prepared and has excellent experience, we're just lacking funds to set her free to work.
  • If we can't reach our goal, whatever funding we do get will still go to publicity. Without an audience we have nothing, but hard working artists playing to empty seats. Meaning all other funds we've raised will be spent with no hope of moving forward.

The Impact

  • Without your help the production's World Premiere will be only be a workshop of sorts. 
  • House Red has been productin theatre since 2000 in Atlanta, Minneapolis and Los Angeles. This is our first production in New York City. We want to give the audiences a memorable experience, one that could spark us on to our next venture. Your support will allow us to reach people and help us continue on in a highly competitive city.
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

  • The risk is high for us because of this being our first production Off-Broadway. This could either make us or break us-literally.
  • We have a smart and talented and experience team to see this project through despite the possible short comings of funds. We will not stop no matter what we receive in funding here. It will be four years by the time we open. That committment is outstanding and we want the team to reep what they've sown. We risk having little to no viewers without your help, which could be devastating to our cause.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't offer funds, you can offer your time by spreading the word on social media. That is great publicity too!
  • by using Indiegogo share tools you can get the word out about us. That could bring possible contributors to our campaign.
  • Please come on board and help us bring this play to Off-Broadway with a stage star who loves the script and wants to give us a boost.

story:
Short Summary

We need your help to bring this project to it's final stages. Projects about sex work made by sex workers are not traditionally funded. We have been turned town by several funders, citing that this project "conflicts with our mission and values." We are committed to creating spaces for sex workers to disseminate their own knowledge, stories and art. We are now turning to our communities and social circles to help make this happen. We hope that when We're Still Working  project  is a wild success, this will show more traditional funders that supporting sex workers is a necessary an important community investment. 

Sex work has a long and beautiful history of fighting for justice, visibility and respect, while working in solidarity with other movements of our time. Sex workers have played an important role in shaping the world we live in today - from Stonewall in New York to the Compton Cafeteria uprising in the Tenderloin here in San Francisco. However, the sex worker is often distorted or erased in the final accounts of their histories by news media, cinema and history books. This project recognizes workers and our intersecting communities as an important part of the San Francisco Bay Area, and honors sexual labor as an integral part of its history and artistic legacy. This visual art exhibit provides a platform for the brush, the camera, the mic, the sequins and sweat to insist that sex work is not only work, but also can be art. This visual art exhibition was recently awarded a Curatorial Residency at SOMArts Cultural Center in San Francisco. The exhibition will be on view in SOMArts’ Main Gallery from January 26–February 25, 2017. 

We strongly believe that placing sex workers at the center of our own narrative is one of the best ways to fight for sex worker justice. We have partnered with the St. James Infirmary, El/La Para Trans Latinas, and LYRIC LGBTQ Youth Center to bring you a gallery full of brilliant, impactful artwork made by sex workers. Our goal is to addresses the complexities of sex work in a way that does not further perpetuate negative stereotypes, damaging rhetoric, the over-glamorization or simplification of the trade. We are not outsiders examining the sex worker community, but insiders with art to share. Art is a form of activism, and we are committed to creating this opportunity for sex workers to share our stories through artistic outlets at SOMArts Main Gallery this January.

Participating Artists:

  • Aida Lizalde in collaboration with Julius Caesar 
  • Ana Quintanilla in collaboration with Sthefany Galante Bautista & Lluvia Chávez 
  • Arabelle Raphael 
  • Brothel Girl 
  • Chucha Marquez & Gina de Vries in collaboration with youth from LYRIC LGBTQ Center​
  • Grace Mendenhall in collaboration with Juliette Stray 
  • Jacq The Stripper 
  • Joseph Liatela 
  • Emmet Logan in collaboration with Kalash Ka 
  • Lake Anderson 
  • Laurenn McCubbin
  • Logout
  • Lyric Seal aka Neve Be 
  • Pluma Sumaq​
  • Rae Threat 
  • Shae Rayder Walsh 

Curated By:

  • Maxine Holloway
  • Javier Luis Hurtado
  • River Black

In conjunction with: 

  • Rob Fatal
  • Christopher Gates
  • Kalash Ka
  • St James Infirmary
  • El/La Trans Latinas
  • LYRIC LGBTQ Youth Center

What We Need & What You Get

We need $6000 more dollars to give this project life. Our sex worker artists and community partners have been woking tremendously hard over the past few months to create truly unique collection of art work and events that fight for sex worker justice, are though provoking, and are beautiful. SOMArts Cultural Center has provided a great foundation for this show to come to life. Now we just need a final financial push to present this project in the way that it deserves.

  • $2000 of these funds will be going to raise the artists & performer stipend for each participating artist. Supporting our artists who are sharing their complex struggles and triumphs of being a sex worker within a culture that stigmatizes us, is our number one priority.
  • $500 will go towards organizing our sex worker health panel with LYRIC LGBTQ Youth Center
  • $500 will go to the Failed Films Presents: #FuckYouPayMe, sex workers & film night
  • $1500 will go to artwork shipping and installation.
  • $1500 to compensate the three main curators for producing this project.
  • $300 to offset the fee taken by indiegogo

*any additional funds raised will go directly to the artists, then curators.

Please Share this campaign far & wide!

Even if you are unable to give at this time, please share this campaign to let our communities know about this show happening January 26 - Feb 25! 

We hope to celebrate with you all at the Opening Reception: January 26, 2017  6-9p

We have been turned town by several funders, citing that this project "conflicts with our mission and values." We are committed to creating spaces for sex workers to disseminate their own knowledge, stories and art. We are now turning to our communities and social circles to help make this happen. We hope that when We're Still Working  project  is a wild success, this will show more traditional funders that supporting sex workers is a necessary an important community investment. 
Sex work has a long and beautiful history of fighting for justice, visibility and respect, while working in solidarity with other movements of our time. Sex workers have played an important role in shaping the world we live in today - from Stonewall in New York to the Compton Cafeteria uprising in the Tenderloin here in San Francisco. However, the sex worker is often distorted or erased in the final accounts of their histories by news media, cinema and history books. This project recognizes workers and our intersecting communities as an important part of the San Francisco Bay Area, and honors sexual labor as an integral part of its history and artistic legacy. This visual art exhibit provides a platform for the brush, the camera, the mic, the sequins and sweat to insist that sex work is not only work, but also can be art. This visual art exhibition was recently awarded a Curatorial Residency at SOMArts Cultural Center in San Francisco. The exhibition will be on view in SOMArts’ Main Gallery from January 26–February 25, 2017. 
We strongly believe that placing sex workers at the center of our own narrative is one of the best ways to fight for sex worker justice. We have partnered with the St. James Infirmary, El/La Para Trans Latinas, and LYRIC LGBTQ Youth Center to bring you a gallery full of brilliant, impactful artwork made by sex workers. Our goal is to addresses the complexities of sex work in a way that does not further perpetuate negative stereotypes, damaging rhetoric, the over-glamorization or simplification of the trade. We are not outsiders examining the sex worker community, but insiders with art to share. Art is a form of activism, and we are committed to creating this opportunity for sex workers to share our stories through artistic outlets at SOMArts Main Gallery this January.
Participating Artists: 

Aida Lizalde in collaboration with Julius Caesar 
Ana Quintanilla in collaboration with Sthefany Galante Bautista & Lluvia Chávez 
Arabelle Raphael 
Brothel Girl 
Chucha Marquez & Gina de Vries in collaboration with youth from LYRIC LGBTQ Center​
Grace Mendenhall in collaboration with Juliette Stray 
Jacq The Stripper 
Joseph Liatela 
Emmet Logan in collaboration with Kalash Ka 
Lake Anderson 
Laurenn McCubbin
Logout
Lyric Seal aka Neve Be 
Pluma Sumaq​
Rae Threat 
Shae Rayder Walsh 

Curated By:

Maxine Holloway
Javier Luis Hurtado
River Black

In conjunction with: 

Rob Fatal
Christopher Gates
Kalash Ka
St James Infirmary
El/La Trans Latinas
LYRIC LGBTQ Youth Center


What We Need & What You Get
We need $6000 more dollars to give this project life. Our sex worker artists and community partners have been woking tremendously hard over the past few months to create truly unique collection of art work and events that fight for sex worker justice, are though provoking, and are beautiful. SOMArts Cultural Center has provided a great foundation for this show to come to life. Now we just need a final financial push to present this project in the way that it deserves.

$2000 of these funds will be going to raise the artists & performer stipend for each participating artist. Supporting our artists who are sharing their complex struggles and triumphs of being a sex worker within a culture that stigmatizes us, is our number one priority.
$500 will go towards organizing our sex worker health panel with LYRIC LGBTQ Youth Center
$500 will go to the Failed Films Presents: #FuckYouPayMe, sex workers & film night
$1500 will go to artwork shipping and installation.
$1500 to compensate the three main curators for producing this project.
$300 to offset the fee taken by indiegogo

*any additional funds raised will go directly to the artists, then curators.

Please Share this campaign far & wide!
Even if you are unable to give at this time, please share this campaign to let our communities know about this show happening January 26 - Feb 25! 
We hope to celebrate with you all at the Opening Reception: January 26, 2017  6-9p

story:
Ladle Facial Makeup

 

MISSION

Welcome, thank you to our community！

We are a social startup business to change the status quo and to let more marginalized women folk art craftsmen obtain income. We hope that the fossils art spread to all over the world and will enable them to pick up tools, will enable art to shining victory.

Basing on previous experience, we hope that by doing the Internet promotion, cultural exhibition, and the professional training of the artist to make China Shaanxi Ladle Facial Makeup craftsman to raise income. We hope that you and more people love and support of the folk artwork.

 

CURRENT SITUATION

Feel sad is that current Ladle Facial Makeup craftsman income is very low. Because of the lack of promotion and sales channels in the local, many marginalized women and the old craftsmen have no source of income, part of the craftsman has given up the inheritance of workmanship, and plow land to survive.

 

OUR PLANS

A good vintage car, if it did not have the opportunity to become the exhibits, If there is no favorite people to collect it, it will become a scrap iron. Also, we plan to let Ladle Facial Makeup shine brilliantly in our way. Setting up the Internet community interaction, cooperating with the restaurant to chain sales and opening city art exhibition will be able to let more people love and support it. We will help more marginalized women and the old craftsmen to obtain income. By establishing a production center and completing professional training, they will be reflected to advantage.

We will feel more confident, if you can become part of the story of our Ladle Facial Makeup.

 

Click Here to go back to the top to support us!

story:
The Independence Day Project....

The Independence Day is about creating a shared vision of Black independence from the systems of control that have created stagnation instead of progress towards an independently self-sufficient Black community. Several documentaries have corrected the misgivings of our cultural contributions and historical status as they have presented truth to shed light on the propagated lies as seen in the media and textbook accounts of Africans in  America so we stand on their shoulders as we present a movie that will take the discussion to the next point in it's progression, the future. 

This movie project is a game changer as it not only rehash the history but we will also present a vision of what a liberated Black community would resemble and by utilizing the Nine Areas of Human Activity as described by Dr. Neely Fuller we will present a road map on how to get there.

Those nine areas of activity are....

1. Economics
2. Education
3. Entertainment
4. Labor
5. Law
6. Politics
7. Religion
8. Sex
9. War/Counter-War

 

In addition to this subject areas we will address the changes that we must adhere to culturally to create the mindset necessary for us to change our condition and proceed to our promise of Black Independence!

In order to make this project work we are going to need help from you....

We have powerful and amazing historians and people with vision all over the country so we need funds for transportation costs, photographers, editors, and the little things that often occur when trying to complete a project of this magnitude. 

In order to provide the best quality film possible we need the equipment to make that happen. We want to produce a high quality film and you deserve to receive the best product possible!

Imagine trying to go somewhere that you have never been, without a map or an understanding of your destination how would you know where to go or what it would look like when you got there or better yet, imagine how insane must have sounded to have people walking on the moon in the 50's only to see it come to fruition less than 20 years later. That was accomplished with vision, the same type of vision that we, here at The Independence Day Project have for our community! 

This project is needed because it will be the first to give a clear and transparent view of what an independent Black Community is supposed to resemble when the purposely placed obstacles have been removed! 

We have had successful Black Communities in the past but they were not connected and they could not protect themselves from the angry mobs that eventually destroyed them and removed them from the history books. We are looking to spark the thought processes and bring the realization of institution building and self-assurance by presenting a visual that will make a clear understanding of an independent community that breeds a proactive spirit yearning to be free! 

We have been apart of several successful projects in the past whether it be back to school drives or presenting needy families with food and clothes within the community. Just last year What About Us? put together a book reading initiative that raised monies to sponsor children who read books while on summer vacation. The point is, when we are committed we follow through and we are sincerely committed to this project!

So, you must be asking yourselves, who is this Professor Carl Tone Jones and this What About Us? Organization?

Upon obtaining his Master's Degree in Social Studies-Citizenship, Professor Carl Tone Jones worked vigorously in the Philadelphia Public School system. As a professor, he also teaches courses in the area of community leadership. An accomplished lecturer, writer and public speaker, Jones has become a beacon of hope within the community as he strives to continue his focus concerning the improvement of the socio-economic conditions of the African born Americans as well as descendants of the African Diaspora. He continues to work with at-risk youths helping them to develop and utilize critical thinking skills through his workshops and lectures.

"What About Us?" began as a workshop that I created ​to address the plight of black adolescents who were considered at-risk youths struggling to assess their social constructs as they related to morality, value structures and critical thinking. The motivation behind the workshop was due to the untimely death of a close relative at the hands of another youth here in the streets of North Philadelphia. But even before that unfortunate incident I had taken an interest in securing a role in the preservation and uplift of the black community by working with youths and teaming with like minded people to form coalitions to battle the systems of white supremacy. Hopefully, this site will become a place of strength, information sharing and strategic creation as we move forward in these challenging times.

So, How Can You Assist Us If You Do Not Have $$$?

There are a few ways in which you can assist with the project if you don't have the capability to make a monetary contribution:

You can share this crowdfund on your social media platforms such as Twitter, Facebook and Instagram using the Hashtag #ProjectIndependence and #BlackIndependenceorDie

You can also use the Indiegogo sharing tools as well as word of mouth advertising. 

Family, 

Let's work together to be a part of the project that changed to focus and the vision of the Black Liberation Movement! 

Ase' Family,

Professor Carl Tone Jones, M. Ed.
